Graphical abstract This review offers a comprehensive overview of non-precious group metal (non-PGM) electrocatalysts, with a particular focus on oxygen reduction reactions (ORR). The main challenge preventing the broad commercial use of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) is the dependence on noble metals, specifically electrocatalyst (EC) based on platinum (Pt) at the cathode, which is indispensable for assisting the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in fuel cells (FCs). Research on EC-containing non-noble metal (NNM) has been considerable over the past few decades to minimize costs and reduce the excessive loading of EC based on Pt. This review is aimed at improving the reliability and stability of non-precious metal EC. To achieve a feasible ORR, Pt-based EC is crucial for the widespread commercial applications of PEMFCs. The review emphasizes improving ORR performance, stability, and cost-effectiveness in catalysts that are not precious metals. The article examines the advancements in non-precious nanomaterial-based EC, highlighting different types that have improved ORR efficiency. The review suggests future possibilities and directions for further improvement in designing and constructing EC with high efficiency and low costs for PEMFCs. Keywords Fuel cells Oxygen reduction reaction Electrocatalyst Non-noble metal Nanomaterial 1 Introduction The global energy demand has experienced a significant surge, primarily driven by the current rate of population growth [1,2]. An alarming issue is the substantial reliance on fossil fuels to meet this energy demand [3–5]. Fossil fuels, nonrenewable resources, pose considerable drawbacks and are implicated in environmental issues, notably global warming. As a result, it is imperative to explore reliable and ecologically sustainable alternatives for energy generation. Fuel cell (FC) technologies have emerged as a viable alternative to fossil fuels for producing clean energy in response to this imperative over the past few decades [6–10]. Polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) are highly regarded for efficiently converting chemical energies to electricity through electrochemical processes. Compared to other fuel cell technologies, they are thought to be the best for both stationary and mobile uses because they have a high energy density, a short start-up time, high efficiency, no toxic emissions, silent operation, low operating temperature, the ability to work in stop-and-go driving conditions, and are easy to handle safely [11–13]. Fig. 1 indicates the evolution of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) catalysts and the commercialization of FC [14,15]. Despite these advantages, challenges impeding their commercialization include issues related to durability and cost [16,17]. The successful commercialization of PEMFCs necessitates careful consideration of durability and cost. In this regard, the minimum lifetime requirements established by the American Department of Energy (DOE) for stationary applications stand at 40,000 h, while they approximate 5000 h for automotive applications [18,19]. While recent efforts have aimed at reducing costs and enhancing durability, foundational innovations in PEMFC technology are imperative to facilitate sustainable commercialization. In general, the lifetime of PEMFCs can be compromised by factors such as water management systems, thermal and power cycling, and degradation of the membrane electrode assembly (MEA) [20–23]. Carbon corrosion, Pt accumulation, or MEA degradation may result from these issues [24–31]. Degradation can happen in extreme situations, including high oxygen (O2) levels passing through the membranes or poor control of operational factors such as a lack of reactants and fuel [32–34]. This leads to a process in which the active layer does not contain sufficient gas [35,36]. Consequently, extensive efforts are being made globally to comprehend the degradation mechanisms and achieve the lifetime previously mentioned objectives. Recently, there has been a focus on the mechanisms for the degradation of electrocatalysts (EC) that are supported by Pt and carbon, and emphasized problems related to fuel and oxidant shortages, considering the extensive literature on impurities and water management in this field [37–40]. Furthermore, the quantity of Pt required in FCs has been significantly reduced owing to economic considerations, with concentrations as low as 0.4 mg cm−2 or even lower at the cathode and 0.05 mg cm−2 at the anode [41]. This reduction has been achieved progressively by replacing Pt with carbon-based structures. However, the catalysis of carbon support oxidation by Pt and the subsequent release of sustained catalyst nanoparticles (NPs) cause a diminish in active surface area, significantly impacting the ORR performance [42–45]. According to an anticipated cost for large-scale FC production, research conducted by the DOE has established that the Pt EC layers are responsible for 56% of the expenses in a PEMFC stack [46]. This expenditure is a result of the considerable quantity of catalysts based on Pt that is required in both the cathode catalyst layer, which is responsible for catalyzing the ORR, and the anode catalyst layer, which is responsible for catalyzing the hydrogen (H2) oxidation reaction (HOR). Anodic HOR leads to relatively slow ORR kinetics for the cathode. This is due to the need to overcome the strong energy bonds between oxygen molecules, particularly in low-pH environments. To facilitate this process, a large amount of platinum (Pt) catalyst, approximately eight times more than the anode catalyst, is required. However, this leads to high overpotential and limits the performance of PEMFCs [47,48]. Pt-based EC are recognized as effective materials due to their superior catalytic properties. However, prohibitive expenses, resource limitations, vulnerability to toxicity, and insufficient stability impede their practical usage. Therefore, effective, robust, and cost-effective ORR EC are crucial for attaining [49,50]. In recent decades, several design approaches and engineering methodologies were created to improve ORR performance by making refined adjustments to the nanostructures, doping arrangement, and porosity of nanostructures. Collaborative efforts from experimental and theoretical scientists have yielded insightful perspectives into the ORR process on carbon materials without metal. Considerable research has been done to improve the efficiency of ORR EC by creating new nanostructures with increased surface areas and active sites to enhance ORR efficiency. The complicated mechanism and sluggish kinetics of ORR remain insufficiently understood, primarily owing to challenges in precisely identifying active sites and the intricate proton/electron transfer pathways to O2 molecules, despite much research and notable progress over the years [51–55]. Herein, we offer a summary of recent developments in NNMEC for ORR, along with prospects for designing nanomaterials as very effective EC for ORR in PEMFCs. To enhance PEMFC technology with NNMEC, research endeavors have broadened to include a variety of prospective materials, a few of which have undergone evaluation in recent times [56–59]. The term “catalyst performance” is used to simplify the situation by referring to the ORR electro-kinetics that take place on these nanomaterials, which are normally evaluated at large electrode potentials [60–63]. The electrochemical efficiency is assessed on a volumetric basis, considering that NNMEC is relatively more economical than Pt-metal EC. Consequently, increased loading becomes less critical when the catalyst layer thickness approaches 100 mm; however, at this point, mass transport issues may emerge [64,65]. Electrochemical performance is a comprehensive measure of ORR electro-kinetics over a broad potential range, considering electron transport, mass transfer, and the structural and chemical characteristics of various catalyst architectures. Non-noble electrocatalytic materials are tested for stability and durability by examining how well they maintain activity and performance following accelerated degradation tests. 2 Literature review 2.1 PEMFC description A basic PEMFC has seven primary layers: the cathode catalyst layer, the proton exchange membrane, the hydrogen diffusion layer, the hydrogen flow plate, the anode catalyst layer, the air diffusion layer, and the airflow plate. In PEMFCs, the anode and cathode are separated via a solid ionomer membrane that facilitates proton transport between the two electrodes. The electrodes can conduct electricity, while the membrane serves as an ionic conductor, allowing for physical separation between them. Traditional fuels like compressed gaseous hydrogen are accepted by the anode, while an oxidant like atmospheric oxygen is accepted by the cathode. Electrons and protons are created via the oxidation of hydrogen by the anode. Protons are transported through the membrane over the cathode by the electrochemical potential gradient. The cathode receives electrons from the outside circuit. At the cathode, electrons and protons recombine, where they engage in the ORR with water. PEMFCs are characterized by their high-power density, which is attributed to the electrolyte membrane, which is typically a thin layer with a thickness of roughly 20 µm and a lightweight composition. Due to the electrolyte substance utilized in the FC, the operating temperature of PEMFCs is established. Typically, membrane materials are derived from perfluorinated H2O3S polymers, such as Nafion or Aquivion. PEMFCs with perfluorinated H2O3S polymers operate effectively at temperatures below 100 °C, depending on liquid water for proton conductivity in cold environments [66]. It is vital to use noble-metal catalysts at these temperatures to facilitate reactions at the electrodes. This is because they are less vulnerable to being poisoned by impurities, and they are also better able to handle water management at these temperatures. Fig. 2 indicates a scheme of acidic and basic FCs [67]. The current research is concentrated on advancing ORR catalysts in the cathode of PEMFCs. Additionally, PEMFCs offer several advantages, including (I) production of electrical energy, avoiding the “thermal bottleneck” associated with the second law of thermodynamics [68], making them more efficient than combustion engines that first converted chemical energy into heat and then converted mechanical energy, (II) FC vehicles emit only water and minimal heat, representing a significant improvement over internal combustion engines, (III) PEMFCs, do not have any components that move, which increases their dependability in comparison to conventional engines, (IV) Hydrogen, the preferred fuel for PEMFCs, is often readily generated, whereas the procedures involved in oil extraction and refining have detrimental effects on the environment. The MEA constitutes the core of PEMFC. Elevating the operating voltage under practically relevant load situations is a crucial element in advancing PEMFC technology. Four main parts constitute the MEA: the proton exchange membrane (PEM), the gas diffusion layers (GDLs) for the anode and cathode, the catalyst layers (CL), and the microporous layer (MPL), which is usually part of the GDL. 2.2 Effect of CL on MEA efficiency Pt NPs catalyst, usually, is used to construct the CL in both the anode and cathode, and they are supported by carbon black materials with a large surface area and an ionomer. Electrochemical reactions occur at the interface of the three phases: catalyst, ionomer, and reactant. The kinetics of the ORR at the cathode is more sluggish than that of the HOR at the anode. Boosting catalysts' natural catalytic activities can help speed up slow ORR kinetics, which in turn makes MEA work better. Furthermore, mass transport capabilities inside the catalyst layers are increasingly critical for the efficiency attributes of the MEA. The meticulous design of catalyst layers, incorporating optimum pore structure, thickness, and ionomer content, emerged as a crucial determinant in enhancing MEA performance. However, the impacts resulting from alterations in CL preparation are interrelated. The quantity of ionomer required for proton transport and the formation of the triple phase area in both catalyst layers influences catalytic activity, water management, reactant permeability, and ionic resistance concurrently [69]. The permeability of oxygen increases as the thickness of the ionomer film in the catalyst layer decreases [70]. An excessively thick ionomer film in the CL enhances proton conductivity but concurrently elevates reactant diffusion resistance, therefore diminishing MEA performance. Furthermore, it can negatively affect the cell's water management by obstructing certain pores in the CL. Conversely, insufficient ionomer content can diminish ionic conductivity and lower the active triple-phase region [71,72]. To get the best performance from the MEA, it is important to utilize the right amount of ionomer in the catalyst layer. Another approach to enhancing MEA performance may involve minimizing the electrical resistance of each catalyst layer. This is attained by decreasing the thickness of the catalyst layer through the utilization of catalysts with high platinum content, leading to an enhancement of the linear segments of the I-V characteristics of the MEA. The thickness of the CL influences water management and the response to changes in operational circumstances [73,74]. The ink compositions and selecting an appropriate MEA preparation can enhance efficiency. 2.3 Effect of PEM on MEA efficiency The type of membrane can significantly alter the efficiency parameters of the MEA [75]. Generally, thinner membranes result in reduced ohmic resistance, therefore enhancing MEA efficiency [76]. However, thinner membranes result in heightened hydrogen crossing and alterations in the back diffusion of product water. Both effects are impacting the durability and performance of MEA. The PEM in MEA facilitates isolated electron transfer, segregates gas reactants, and facilitates proton migration and transmission. The fundamental criteria for PEMs encompass elevated ionic conductivity, appropriate water absorption capacity, superior mechanical qualities in dry and hydrated conditions, robust thermal stability, minimal air permeability, electrochemical stability, and a controlled swelling rate. The Nafion series of perfluorosulfonic acid (PFSA) membranes has been primarily employed in low-temperature photovoltaic FCs because of its superb mechanical and thermal stability and remarkable proton conductivity [77]. The PFSA molecule contains a sulfonic acid functional group, a perfluoroethylene side chain, and a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) backbone [78]. The Mechanical and chemical stability of PEM is specified with the hydrophobic main chain of PTFE [79]. Proton conductivity is primarily dependent on the sulfonic acid groups as the primary active elements. PFSA membranes can be classified into long-side chain (LSC) and short-side chain (SSC) membranes based on the length of their side chains. The SSC membranes can hold more water, have better ionic conductivity and comparable mechanical properties, and have a greater glass transition temperature [80], therefore demonstrating enhanced performance in MEA, especially under low humidity conditions. Because they have a higher ion exchange capacity (IEC), SSC membranes have a lot more water in them. This means that the network of hydrophobic channels is not as well established as it is in LSC membranes. The proton conductivity of the PFSA membrane is typically enhanced by reduced temperature and elevated humidity. An elevated operating temperature will result in membrane deterioration and failure due to desiccation. On the other hand, in cold environments, the polymer chain sequesters a portion of the water, causing it to rapidly freeze on the membrane surface. Pinholes readily develop on the membrane surface, adversely impacting the performance of the MEA. As a result, the PFSA membrane needs to be at the right temperature for it to conduct and absorb water. 2.4 Effect of GDL on MEA efficiency GDL typically comprises a substrate layer and an MPL. It is applied to the hydrophobically modified substrate layer [81]. In MEAs, the MPL is in direct contact with the CL, while the substrate layer interfaces with the external bipolar plate (BPP) [82]. The GDL's role in the MEA is to offer robust mechanical support and corrosion resistance to safeguard the CL and ensure excellent interfacial contact with the CL and BPP, and smooth flow transmission channels (like heat, electricity, and water) [83]. The GDL is used to effectively transmit electrons between the BPP and CL during the operation of an FC, while the CL's heat is passed onto the BPP through the GDL. Consequently, the GDL primarily fulfills the essential roles of transmitting electricity and heat, as well as conveying reaction gasses. Proper hydrophilicity is necessary for the GDL at the anode to provide enough water for the membrane and ionomer to facilitate proton conduction. Nonetheless, the cathode reaction generates a substantial quantity of water (particularly in intensive operational situations), a portion of which migrates by the PEM to the anode, whereas the remainder must be effectively expelled by the GDL to the flow regions [84]. Flooding at the cathode can cause many issues due to inadequate exhaust. Water management differs between the cathode and anode sides. Thus, the hydrophobicity of the GDL located on the cathode must be higher than that located near the anode [85]. GDLs on both sides must show an appropriate porosity, pore distribution, and pore architecture to facilitate the ingress of liquid water from CL into GDL [86]. Optimizing MPLs is widely recognized as an effective method for enhancing water management [87]. MPL lowers the contact resistance between the CL and GDL, limits catalyst ink from getting into the GDL, and prevents the loss of active material. The optimization and enhancement of MPLs now focus on (i) the thickness of MPLs [88]; (ii) the pore distribution and porosity [89]; (iii) modifications of MPLs that are either hydrophobic or hydrophilic [90,91]; (iv) MPLs that contain multiple layers of hydrophilic and hydrophobic material [92]; and (v) structures modifications (such as cracks and perforations that serve as the pathway for liquid water to reach the substrate layer, etc.) [93]. If you want to optimize the GDL's water management performance, perforating it can also be a useful optimization strategy. This process breaks down the hydrophobic layer, allowing some hydrophilic pores to enter the diffusion channels surrounding the water channels. This method improves the GDL's wettability and removes liquid water at the same time, resulting in improved water management and MEA performance [94]. 2.5 Working principle of PEMFC H2 is directed through the catalyst into the FC at the anode under pressure. Upon encountering the Pt on the catalyst, the H2 molecule undergoes a split into two entities: protons or H+ ions and electrons (e−). The transmission of electrons is from the anode, passes by using the exterior circuit, and then returns to the cathode. Concurrently, O2 is compelled through the catalyst at the cathode, leading to the formation of two O2 atoms. Atoms of O2 possess a potent negative charge, which draws H+ ions towards them across the membrane. This interaction results in the formation of a water molecule (H2O). These reactions occur within a cell stack, which is integrated into a unit that includes water, air management, fuel, and coolant control software and hardware. This unit is then incorporated into a complete system suitable for various technological applications. Due to the FCs' high efficiency (55%), this remarkable technology finds utility in diverse applications like transportation (buses, cars, forklifts, vehicles, etc.) and backup power generation during electricity network failures. 2.6 Working mechanism of the ORR The operational mechanism of the ORR is contingent upon various factors, including intermediates involved in the reaction pathway. A comprehensive examination has been conducted regarding ORR catalysts, encompassing nanostructures, catalytic activity, and stability. Presently, ORR stands as one of the most pivotal challenges in electrocatalysis, serving as an indispensable cathodic process in FCs [95–97]. Additionally, the production of four O–H bonds and the breaking of double bonds are both components of the complex four-electron reaction pathway, which includes essential steps and transitional species [98,99]. Several researches have investigated the rate of the ORR in an acidic environment utilizing nanostructures made of Pt supported on carbon. Some research endeavors have primarily concentrated on optimizing the O2 cathode structure and electrochemical efficiency. Theoretical assessments and computations enhance experimental results and assist the acquisition of kinetic parameters. Research is scarce on the ORR mechanism, specifically on nanostructures made of Pt. Therefore, the mechanism is deduced but not definitively explained. Despite extensive and rigorous experimental and theoretical investigation spanning several decades, the specific mechanism of the ORR remains unknown. This lack of clarity is attributed to several factors. Firstly, current experimental systems lack proficiency in detecting all potential reaction intermediates within a complex process. Furthermore, the reaction takes place in an area with a large over-potential, and the activation zone is limited to the beginning of the wave alone. This leads to the swift emergence of the transport-controlled region, limiting the potential range for a true analysis of the electron transfer mechanism. Therefore, it is crucial to employ innovative experimental approaches and theoretical computations to elucidate the features and processes associated with ORR electrocatalysis. 2.7 Characteristics of ORR EC in half-cell testing systems The evaluation of the industrial and practical potential of ORR EC is considered sophisticated when using the MEA to determine power density. The sequence of events in the process is unclear, as it is questionable if the initial step involves the O2 atom separation or if the steps of reduction occur before the breaking of the O–O bond. Some well-known scientists, including Griffith, Pauling, and Bridge, have postulated three distinct forms of O2 sorption to supply an answer to this topic. In the field of inorganic chemistry, these three bonding models are generally acknowledged, and it is thought that they occur for compounds based on platinum. According to the Griffith model, the O2 molecule interacts with a single substrate atom through a robust connection, particularly between the π and vacant dz 2 orbitals of the atoms on the metal surface [101]. The Pauling model delineates the process of “end-on adsorption by a single-type bond”, in which the electron density of the acceptor dz 2 orbitals is supplied by the π orbital of the O2 molecule [102]. On the other hand, the Bridge model clarifies the reaction that occurs between two robust connections with two distinct active sites for nanomaterials based on Pt, as suggested by the Yeager principle [103]. Electrical potential, precise temperature, and concentration all have an impact on the catalytic characteristics of clustered materials. Structural modifications to the electrolyte additives and electrode surface accelerate the electrode reaction. Since the start of the 20th century, the Sabatier principle has served as a conceptual foundation for our understanding of the most effective catalyst. The concept is that the most effective catalysts should form bonds with atoms and molecules of intermediate strength. This means that the bonds should not be too weak, since the catalyst has to activate the reactants. However, if the bonds are too strong, they could hinder the release of products and potentially contaminate the catalyst with strongly attached intermediates. This results in a correlation between activity and binding strength that resembles a volcano. A quantitative expression of the Sabatier principle may be established by considering the thermodynamics of individual reaction steps. In this formulation, the free energy of reaction steps that include intermediates bound to the catalyst will be influenced by the characteristics of the catalyst. In the quantitative version of the Sabatier principle, the optimal catalyst is the material in which every reaction step in the sequence is thermodynamically neutral or energetically favorable. In the context of electrochemical equilibrium, this means that every individual step in a reaction mechanism must have the same equilibrium potential as the overall equilibrium potential. Additionally, if the mechanism includes non-electrochemical stages, those steps must have no free reaction energy. The thermodynamic Sabatier approach identifies the “difficult” step in the process as the one that is thermodynamically least favorable if a condition cannot be satisfied. This phase is frequently, but not invariably, identical to the rate-determining step. This theory has proven highly effective in offering a broad qualitative comprehension of the reasons behind the existence of an optimal catalyst. As a heterogeneous catalysis theory, its lack of quantitative nature significantly limits its application. This suggests a lack of precision in forecasting, which prevents experimental testing. The appropriate measure to quantify the “bond strength” between the relevant intermediate and the catalyst, as well as the optimal value of this “bond strength” for the catalyst, remains uncertain. Due to these factors, the Sabatier principle is not applicable as a foundation for catalyst design guidelines. It is now much easier to find organized data on adsorption energies and activation energies in chemical processes that happen on metal surfaces thanks to the development of fast and accurate computational methods for electronic structure. Koper's group [104], has revived the Sabatier technique by integrating it with quantum-chemical calculations, specifically using density functional theory (DFT), for assessing the thermodynamics of the reaction stages in a catalytic mechanism. This methodology enables the “computational screening” of a vast array of catalysts and has demonstrated significant use in the logical advancement of novel catalysts. The method has gained significant popularity in the field of electrocatalysis and has been successfully used in all of the aforementioned electrode reactions. Nevertheless, the thermodynamic method has uncovered significant constraints on multi-step catalytic reactions that involve several intermediates. Specifically, these intermediates in a catalytic process exhibit energy interdependencies known as scaling relationships. The genesis of these scaling relationships may be traced back to the quantum-chemical theory of chemical bonding. The scaling relationships result in the inability to achieve the ideal catalyst, as specified before, due to the unfavorable universal scaling relation between the energies of two or more intermediates, which prevents all reaction steps from being thermodynamically neutral. Unfavorable scaling between the OOH and OH intermediates was discovered to occur for the ORR and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Moreover, several investigations have been conducted on diverse charge transfer intermediate models on distinct surface types, along with the corresponding reactivity descriptors indicated below. The attention has been focused on two reactivity descriptors, the active metal site density (SD [molSite cm−2]) or (SDmass [Site gcat −1]) or (SDVol [Site cm−3]), and the catalytic turn-over frequency (TOF [s−1]) or [electron site−1 s−1], that is the electrons transferred per active site per second [105]. Enhancing one or both of these characteristics indicates high EC activity. The amalgamation of TOF and SD can be regarded as a meticulous evaluation of catalysts. There are several methods to estimate TOF, and it is crucial to understand how these estimations are made. A common method for measuring both SD, or better the gravimetric site density (SDmass [Site gcat −1]), and TOF denoted by the ex-situ low temperature (or cryo) CO chemisorption/desorption. SD can be determined using an electrochemical approach that relies on the adsorption of nitrite and the electrostripping of NO in situ. The two previously described in situ and ex-situ approaches allow for a precise calculation of the reactivity characteristics of PGM-free catalysts, yielding equivalent findings. Typically, TOF values obtained by CO chemisorption tend to be somewhat lower than those derived using nitrite stripping. This discrepancy may be caused by an overestimation of the associated standard deviation or the use of different approaches to compute the kinetic current in the two routes. Additionally, the disparity between the ability to access gas-phase (CO chemisorption) and electrochemical (nitrite reactivity) properties also contributes to the variation in results obtained when evaluating the standard deviation using in situ or ex-situ techniques. It will ultimately lead to a more precise evaluation of the system's structural dynamics. 2.9 Effect of basic environment in ORR Since the ORR is a facile and direct method, it provides opportunities to investigate alternative EC that are not dependent on platinum. This includes researching the use of MOs and substances based on carbon in basic environments. Despite this, the ORR capability of these ECs is not even close to being on par with what can be accomplished with platinum. Our objective is to develop new material designs and get a thorough comprehension of the surface structure attributes that impact the sorption energies of intermediates and the efficacy of ORR in PEMFCs. (I) Alkaline mediums possess distinct advantages relative to their acidic counterparts. The electrocatalytic process, characterized by the ORR at the cathode and methanol oxidation at the anode, demonstrates greater efficiency in alkaline solutions than in acidic conditions. (II) Alkaline conditions present an opportunity to utilize economical EC composed of (i) supported groups of precious or non-precious metals and (ii) organometallic and inorganic complexes. (III) The flow of liquid fuel, like methanol, is opposed by the transport of OH− ions and the consequent electro-osmotic drag of H2O, which diminishes the likelihood of crossover problems and the reduction of cathodic overpotential. (IV) Improved water management and a decrease in flooding at the cathode can be achieved by balancing water consumption and production at the cathode. (V) Higher pH values safeguard the ionomer membrane from peroxide radicals, facilitating the use of hydrocarbon-based membranes and eliminating the necessity for costly fluorinated polymers. (VI) Liquid electrolytes are prevented from forming carbonate precipitation by using metal-cation-free hydroxyl ion exchange membranes. (VII) Alkaline fuel cells (AFCs) offer a wider variety of fuel choices, like ammonia, ethanol, formic acid, oxalic acid, petrol, and xylitol, alongside the more commonly used hydrogen and methanol in acidic media. The alkaline medium facilitates enhanced cleavage of C–C bonds. The AFCs exhibit distinctive characteristics as a result of the alkaline environment present within the cell. It is important to note the impact on reaction rates at the cathode and anode. In an AFC, the cathode demonstrates superior OER and ORR rates compared to an acidic cell. The high alkali conditions present in the AFC account for this phenomenon. To achieve acceptable cell voltages, Pt catalysts often are needed to address slow rates of OER and ORR in PEMFC. However, this raises the total expense associated with the cell. The elevated rates of OER and ORR in an AFC diminish the necessity for Pt catalysts. This enables the utilization of non-PGMs at the cathode, in conjunction with a diverse array of cost-effective polymers and carbon supports that demonstrate outstanding stability. In contrast, the rate of the HOR and hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) at the anode is significantly reduced in alkaline media when compared to acidic environments. The challenge of HOR stems from the necessity to maintain a metal surface predominantly devoid of oxides at an anode potential of 0.1 V relative to the reversible RHE, and ideally at even greater levels. This is crucial for connecting with hydrogen sorption intermediates in the relevant potential range. The development of appropriate catalysts for hydrogen reactions in PEMFCs presents a significant challenge, especially concerning non-PGM catalysts. It is widely recognized that ORR takes place readily in an alkali media. The alteration in thermodynamics takes place as the pH of the solution increases, leading to a related shift in the potential difference. The potential difference is measured at 1.2 V in an acidic solution and 0.4 V in an alkali solution. A rise in surface-free energy is caused by the decrease in potential variation, which ultimately leads to decreased free energy and increased sorption of oxygen and its intermediates. Nonetheless, a restricted selection of catalysts, like Pt in acidic conditions, exhibit a considerable level of O2 adsorption-free energy, allowing for efficient surface binding and promoting the occurrence of ORR. On the other hand, alkali solution promotes surface reactions, allowing for the utilization of catalysts beyond Pt in the oxygen reduction reaction. Additional catalysts employed in the ORR encompass Pt-metal-based catalysts (PGM), including Pt alloys, alongside PGM-free EC made up of noble metals not derived from PGMs, transition metal oxides (TMOs), and carbon-based catalysts. The ORR generally occurs in alkali conditions and adheres to one of two primary mechanisms: (i) 4-electron pathways, in which each O2 molecule is completely reduced to hydroxide (Eq. (6)), or (ii) a mechanism that reduces each O2 molecule to a hydrogen peroxide anion (HO2 −) through 2-electron pathways (Eq. (7)), which is then further reduced to hydroxide via an additional 2-electron pathway (Eq. (8)). Current studies have focused heavily on methods to improve the effectiveness of ORR in nanocatalysts by significantly decreasing the amount of Pt used in electrocatalytic materials. Different techniques are used to produce hybrid materials to maximize surface area and enhance interactions with intermediate species involved in the ORR. However, the ORR activity of carbon EC and MOs is lower than that of Pt-based materials. Scientists are devoting significant effort to comprehensively understanding the surfaces of nanostructures, as this has a substantial impact on intermediate sorption energies and determines the overall effectiveness of the ORR. Protons and electrons transfer simultaneously during the complex ORR process. This process may proceed via two distinct reaction pathways: the 2-electron pathways and the 4-electron pathways, which compete with one another. Typically, the electrosynthesis of H2O2 encompasses two potential reaction pathways. Two different paths exist: the 2-electron ORR (2e−-ORR) and the 2-electron water oxidation reaction (2e−-WOR). Nonetheless, the application of 2e−-WOR faces challenges for large-scale deployment because of the tendency of H2O2 to undergo rapid oxidation. The 2e−-ORR method consistently produces H2O2 with remarkable purity and concentration, yielding only water as a by-product. Although the ORR can produce H2O2 across acidic, alkaline, and neutral environments, the generation of H2O2 in acidic conditions presents certain advantages over alkaline or neutral scenarios. It is important to highlight that H2O2 demonstrates enhanced chemical durability in acidic conditions against alkaline and neutral conditions. This trait significantly obstructs its natural breakdown. Moreover, the advanced PEM device demonstrates the capability to efficiently utilize H2O2 electrosynthesis in acidic conditions, highlighting outstanding ionic conductivity and impressive durability. Additionally, the presence of H2O2 in acidic conditions broadens its potential applications across various industrial processes. Nonetheless, the thermodynamics of H2O2 in the ORR presents challenges. Consequently, it is essential to design and fabricate EC that exhibit great selectivity, low overpotential, and stable efficiency to promote the generation of H2O2 in acidic environments via a 2e−-ORR pathway. 2.11 The design principles of multiphase interfaces during ORR Electrochemical reactions happen at the triple phase boundary (TPB), which is the line where the proton-conducting electrolyte (liquid phase), gas (gas phase), and catalytic active sites (solid phase) meet. Enhancing the ORR catalyst and optimizing hydrogen fuel cell operations can facilitate the formation of additional TPB. The ORR necessitates a semi-hydrophobic environment that optimizes the catalyst's access to oxygen and the aqueous electrolyte. A commercial carbon-based GDL containing a backing layer that is completely hydrophobic and overlaid with a microporous layer that has fine porosity for catalyst loading. The multiphase interface is established by passivating the surface of porous carbon in the GDL microporous layer with oxygen carboxyl and carbonyl functional groups. These functional groups create ORR active sites on the carbon surface and augment the hydrophilicity of the layer. The functionalized area of the GDL creates a semi-hydrophobic catalyst layer (SCL) on the electrolyte-facing side, where the number of active centers and hydrophobicity can be adjusted. In CL design, meticulous regulation of ionomer concentration and distribution is essential to improve proton conductivity and the accessibility of active sites. In addition to CL design, the TPB is affected by PEMFC operation, with factors like flooding, degradation, load cycling, and dehydration potentially altering the TPB area. Analyzing and elucidating the properties of TPB is essential for enhancing the FC performance. Due to the utilization of a solid electrolyte in PEMFCs, the sulfonic groups are anchored to the resin of the PEM, inhibiting penetration into the electrode. Consequently, the TPB is confined to the reaction layer in contact with the PEM. Only the CL and PEM can efficiently conduct protons, requiring the formation of ion channels inside the CL. Furthermore, gaseous reactants must access the catalyst surface, and the produced water must evacuate rapidly, necessitating hydrophobic pathways inside the catalyst layer. The inclusion of ionomers in the CL might fill certain pores; thus, optimizing the ionomer content and distribution is essential for proton conduction and oxygen transport. An optimal catalyst layer must possess a superior electrochemical triple-phase boundary reaction area to facilitate the effective transfer of protons, electrons, water, and oxygen. The efficiency of FCs can be enhanced by increasing TPB, which can also speed up reaction rates and improve electron and ion transport efficiency. Comprehending and enhancing sorption and kinetic reaction at the triple phase boundary is crucial for developing more effective catalysts. Accelerated adsorption and reaction rates facilitate swifter fuel cell activation. The TPB, where the catalyst, pores, and ionomer converge, is crucial for the reaction, particularly with the optimization of the catalyst layer structure, including pore size and tortuosity. The pore architecture of the CL may restrict oxygen diffusion. The TPB demonstrates a significant rise in porosity in a low-porosity environment. Achieving the appropriate TPB density at intermediate porosity depends on balancing the surface area across the three phases, rather than solely focusing on the volume fraction. The TPBs begin to decline upon achieving the ideal TPB density within the high porosity regime. The membrane and active areas inside the CL are crucial to TPB. The PFSA ionomer utilized in membranes, with thickness contingent upon substrate material, ionomer concentration, and solvents, serves as the foundation for the CL ionomer. The weight and side chain length affect the elevated proton conductivity and the adequate gas permeability for oxygen transport to the catalyst sites. Reduced weight and abbreviated side chains result in increased water absorption owing to enhanced hydrophilic channels and elevated micropore volume. The precise regulation of the TPB is crucial for fuel cell performance because (i) adequate water content at the cathode is necessary for effective membrane wetting and proton diffusion; (ii) humidified H2 and O2 gases must readily reach the catalytic site to prevent MEA desiccation, which impedes proton migration in the TPB and diminishes catalytic activity; (iii) the hot-pressing process during MEA fabrication is essential for optimal assembly, ensuring physical contact among the GDL, CL, and PEM, which facilitate both electron and proton conductivities. TPB is essential in ORR. Indeed, ORR transpires within TPB. Enhancing TPB can improve the interaction among the catalyst, electrolyte, and gas phases, therefore augmenting catalytic activity and activation rate. 2.12 Theoretical methodologies for investigating the potential of new ORR EC DFT is the most often applied technique in quantum mechanics for studying new EC at the molecular level. It has opened up new possibilities for systematically designing EC for the ORR [111,112]. DFT's popularity stems from the commendable balance it achieves between calculation accuracy and computational resources utilized in simulations. Computational design has the advantage of concentrating on qualities and interactions when working with ideal structures, although it is still impossible to achieve a thorough description of all of the atoms that are contained within a solid or particle. As a consequence of this, it is vital to apply a technique that restricts the amount of explicitly handled atoms in computations to fully exploit the potential of computational design. At the moment, two ways have been proven to be effective in modeling EC and the ORR. These are the slab method and the cluster method [113–116]. Cluster approach: NPs are represented in the cluster model using a specific number of atoms, and the computational cost is determined by the number of atoms in the cluster. This methodology provides the most optimal criterion for investigating tiny NPs or QDs with sizes ranging from 1 to 2 nm since it allows for the analysis of the edge effects shown by these nanostructures. Choosing the cluster structure for the ORR assessment can be done using two relevant methods. In the initial scenario, the ORR is assessed based on the cluster's most stable configuration. The alternative scenario suggests a configuration characterized by distinct geometric forms, including octahedrons, icosahedrons, and cubes. Slab approach: In the slab model, a solid surface is depicted by periodic boundary constraints and a finite number of atoms. The dimensions of the surface unit cell determine the computational cost of the simulation. This widely used approach explains extended surfaces or nanoparticle surfaces of different nanometer sizes (greater than 2 nm). 2.13 Theoretical prediction of the ORR's electrocatalytic performance The DFT technique creates a crucial understanding of the surface mechanisms involved in EC for the ORR. Bridging the gap between theoretical studies and experimental results poses a primary challenge. Several theoretical indicators have been suggested to establish the connection between electrocatalytic activity for ORR. Essentially, theoretical predictors provide pertinent details about electrocatalytic characteristics or important factors for the ORR. Therefore, this section primarily focuses on the theoretical descriptors that are frequently applied to characterize the electrocatalytic activity of the ORR. Therefore, the researchers undertook a more comprehensive investigation into these descriptors from a more in-depth perspective [117–119]. The Pt/C EC, extensively utilized and studied for the ORR, serves as a benchmark against which the electrocatalytic properties of newly developed EC, whether derived experimentally or through theoretical investigations, are evaluated [120–122]. One of the first methods that may be used in the theoretical investigation of electrocatalysts is the adsorption energy of the ORR intermediates. A volcano-like pattern may be seen in the relationship between the electrocatalytic activity of platinum and other transition metals and the oxygen adsorption energy (OAE) of these elements. Within the category of pure metals, the volcano diagram demonstrates that Pt is the most effective EC. On the other hand, it was discovered that pure Pt acts as an electrocatalyst that is not ideal. The fact that the adsorption energy is affected by the electrical characteristics of the EC is a well-known fact. Consequently, the “d-band theory” was introduced to establish a relationship between electronic characteristics and electrocatalytic activities. The primary framework of this theory is that the adsorption energy of the species on the electrocatalyst surface is contingent upon the electronic structure of the surface. The adsorption energy of reaction intermediates and d-band theory create significant insights into the efficacy of an ORR EC. Nonetheless, the free energy diagram (FED) serves as a tertiary technique that offers more comprehensive insights into the possibility of spontaneous reactions and the rate-determining step (RDS). The adsorption energy of ORR intermediates may be calculated to generate the FED. For a better understanding of the theoretical prediction of the ORR's electrocatalytic performance, Fig. 5 was provided [123]. 2.14 Electrocatalytic activity experimental factors for the ORR The theoretical assessment of EC has led to the proposal of many different markers of electrocatalytic activity. Concurrently, in experimental assessments, the electrocatalytic performances of new EC are directly measured against established benchmarks, such as mercantile Pt/C EC. Typically, two approaches are used to evaluate the electrocatalytic efficiency of the ORR: (I) utilizing a thin-film RDE; (II) evaluating the performance of an MEA in a single cell. Both methods are appropriate for assessing the electrocatalytic activities of ORR. However, RDE is preferred due to its quicker determination of electrocatalytic activity with minimal equipment requirements. The analysis and quantification of ORR EC performances typically involve parameters such as (I) mass activity; (II) specific activity; (III) electrochemical surface area (ECSA). The ECSA is an empirical factor that is essential for determining specific activity. It allows for the comparison of the active area per unit mass of noble metals in the EC. The charge density resulting from the adsorption/desorption of probe species (such as CO, Cu, and H) measured using cyclic voltammetry is frequently used to determine the ECSAs of different EC based on Pt. Specific activity refers to the measurement of the size of PEMFCs needed to produce a specified value of electric current. This is determined by normalizing the kinetic currents via the ECSA. Mass activity is a measure of the efficiency of an EC, specifically in the context of examining new EC for the ORR. It is computed by dividing the kinetic currents by the amount of EC loaded onto the electrode. The calculation of ECSA, mass, and specific activity follows established protocols available in the literature [124]. In-situ characterization is assuming an increasingly significant role in the domain of electrocatalysis. The real-time measurement of catalysts, reactants, and reaction intermediates elucidates the dynamic process of ORR, hence facilitating a precise comprehension of the catalytic mechanism [125]. The ORR process is complex and involves many electrons. By integrating two or more in situ technologies, a more thorough understanding of the response process may be obtained. For example, using in situ infrared spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, and X-ray absorption spectroscopy, it is possible to get chemical information that is specific to the surface. This includes information on the local coordination environment, as well as the structure and oxidation state of the electrocatalyst while the catalysis process is taking place. In situ scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) can offer insights into the changes that occur in adsorbed species during the ORR. Wang et al. [126] used the STM technique to look at how O2 attaches to and decreases the amount of cobalt porphyrin (CoOEP) and phthalocyanine (CoPc). Electrochemical tests demonstrated that CoOEP exhibited greater oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity compared to CoPc. Monolayers of self-assembled CoOEP and CoPc were created on Au (111) substrates and then examined at the molecular level using STM. The molecular imaging directly demonstrated that O2 adsorbed on CoII sites and only to a small extent on CoIII sites. The CoOEP-O2 and CoPc-O2 complexes displayed significant disparity in STM images as a result of O2 binding. The surface coverage of CoOEP-O2 was approximately 1.4 times greater than that of CoPc-O2. The quantitative measurement of O2 adsorption dynamics was achieved by fitting data from potential step experiments. This allowed for the determination of rate constants for O2 adsorption (k ad) and dissociation (k di) on Co centers. The CoOEP compound exhibited larger levels of k ad and k di compared to CoPc, suggesting increased O2 binding kinetics and reduced barriers to Co–O dissociation on CoOEP. By integrating theoretical calculations, one may achieve a more thorough comprehension of the fundamental process and a more profound insight into the response mechanism. An increasingly crucial element in in situ characterization is the advancement of technology that allows for both time-resolved and spatially-resolved measurements. Employing advanced techniques that offer both high temporal and spatial resolution enables the examination of catalytic reaction processes. This allows for the identification of transient intermediates, the determination of rate-limiting steps, the establishment of the catalyst's mechanism, and the elucidation of the reaction pathway. For instance, it is possible to use video-STM with atomic spatial resolution and millisecond temporal resolution in an aqueous solution to uncover the diffusion behavior of the adsorbent on the electrode surface during electrocatalysis at the atomic level. XAS can monitor rapid advancements in catalytic reactions. There are documented instances when synchrotron-based XAS has effectively tracked the catalyst process kinetics over a time period of hundreds of picoseconds [127]. Jiang et al. [128] investigated the occurrence of molecular oxygen activation during intermetallic spacing-optimized iron network-like sites to improve the ORR. In-situ soft XAS and in-situ synchrotron infrared characterizations showed that the optimized intermetallic distances in Fe-HDNSs could activate molecular oxygen in situ by quickly compensating for electrons through the hybridized Fe 3d–O 2p. This process effectively facilitated the breaking of the OO bond to form *O species and greatly reduced side reactions, resulting in faster kinetics for the 4e− ORR. Consequently, the Fe-HDNS catalyst, which was constructed correctly, demonstrated exceptional performance. It achieved a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.89 V against. RHE and a kinetic current density of 72 mA cm−2@0.80 V vs. RHE. These results surpassed the majority of ORR catalysts that do not contain noble metals. XAS is a robust technique that forms the foundation for two distinct approaches, namely X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). XANES spectroscopy offers insights into the electrical configuration of both single and dual metal atoms, whereas EXAFS spectroscopy is employed to uncover details about their coordination environment, consisting of the identity of coordinated atoms, the quantity of coordination, and the length of the bonds. Furthermore, XANES has the capability to offer more intricate insights into the electronic configurations of coordinated atoms, their levels of oxidation, and their spatial configurations [129]. Schröder et al. [130] employed XANES to follow the valence shifts of Mn in an appealing, super-thin, porous MnO x layer on an Ag-thin film. Studies of the Mn-K edge were conducted to examine the effect of the electrochemical environment and ORR conditions. Surprisingly, it was observed that when the ORR was driven at 0.8 VRHE, the Mn underwent a more significant reduction, and the MnO x redox was found to be nonreversible, which differed from studies in an electrolyte saturated with N2. Further, the catalyst surface's reactivity map may be acquired by the usage of SECM. The size of the tip determines the spatial resolution of SECM, which has seen substantial enhancements in recent times. Putnam et al. [131] employed operand SECM to investigate the generation of radicals by a commercially available pyrolyzed Fe-N-C catalyst in real-time, utilizing a redox-active spin trap technique. The SECM experiment demonstrated the consistent generation of OH·, which correlated with the ORR performance. Their findings were extensively supported by electron spin resonance confirmation, which demonstrated that the hydroxyl radical is the primary radical species generated. In addition, the creation of OH· and H2O2 exhibited different patterns. The formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) decreased as the catalyst degraded, indicating a correlation between ROS production and the catalytic activity of the sample. The investigation of the structural sources of ROS production was conducted using model systems, namely iron phthalocyanine (FePc) and Fe3O4 NPs. Both of these systems exhibited substantial creation of hydroxyl radicals (OH∙) during the ORR. The results offered a thorough understanding of the important, yet insufficiently researched, factors related to the creation and impact of ROS on electrocatalytic systems. This has paved the way for a more in-depth analysis of the mechanisms and kinetics employed by SECM. The recently developed scanning electrochemical cell microscopy (SECCM) approach allows for the precise investigation of the catalytic process of ORR in platinum clusters and NPs. This method provides very detailed spatial information and may effectively expose the catalytic activity [132]. The dissolution of Au NPs placed on glassy carbon was investigated by Bernal et al. [133] using a combination of SECCM and EC-TEM. The work was conducted under both potentiostatic and potentiodynamic conditions, by electrolytes consisting of acidified NaCl and H2SO4. By this integrated methodology, they gained valuable insights into the impact of chloride ion presence or absence on electro-dissolution processes. Chronoamperometric experiments using SECCM in the electrolyte containing Cl− ions showed clear and separate current peak events occurring in the dissolution process. These occurrences were ascribed to the delayed dissolution of individual NPs after the quick collapse of the protective layer that forms in the early stages of anodic polarization. This breakdown exposes the metallic gold core to Cl− ions. The statistical examination of these peak occurrences revealed correlations between the applied potential and the temporal distribution of the peak descriptors. The charge expended in each occurrence was examined, revealing that NPs experience partial disintegration followed by rapid re-passivation. The rise in potential led to an increase in the current at its peak and a reduction in the length of these peak occurrences. This may be attributed to the enhanced process of dissolution and faster re-passivation. The initiation time of the highest occurrences had a significantly random characteristic. In-situ EC-TEM test confirmed the findings, showing that the Au NPs dissolve individually at various time intervals and stages, revealing a core–shell structure in the dissolution process. Due to its higher resistance, the shell undergoes prolonged disintegration, occurring particle by particle, once it breaks down. Another significant emerging trend in in-situ characterization is the integration of several in-situ approaches to analyze the electrocatalytic process from many perspectives. For example, the integration of STM and spectroscopic methods offers a thorough analysis for determining the chemical and structural properties of the electrocatalytic system. Tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (TERS) merges the superior spatial resolution of STM with the chemical discriminating capabilities of RS. Electrochemical ETRS (EC-TERS) may be used in a water-based solution to directly investigate the correlation between the structure and EC activity. Su et al. [134] employed EC-TERS to examine the atomic site-specific electronic characteristics of Pt adatoms with varying coordination numbers. This analysis yielded valuable information on the connection between the electrocatalytic activity of Pt catalysts and the localized surface nanostructure. Moreover, the integration of STM and SECM allows for the acquisition of precise and localized data on the electrochemical behavior of the catalyst surface. Edmondson et al. [135] have successfully implemented conductance and electron tunneling SECM on the surface of gold nanocrystal electrodes. It is possible to simultaneously map both the surface features of the substrate and its electrochemical activity. Fe Mossbauer spectroscopy is a very accurate method to assess the coordination state, electron spin states, and electronic surroundings of iron species in EC. It can identify variations in the energy levels of Fe nuclei and differentiate between Fe species that have comparable coordination settings. Identifying the active centers and electrocatalytic intermediates is very advantageous. Wang et al. [136] employed Fe Mossbauer spectroscopy to differentiate between various Fe types. The SA-FeIII/SNPC profile (Fig. 6 a) was successfully modeled using two doublets, corresponding to FeN x groups with Fe (III) in high-spin (D1) and low-spin (D2) sites, respectively. The lack of singlet and sextet peaks, which correspond to α-Fe and γ-Fe, respectively, indicates the absence of any crystalline phase of iron metal in SA-FeIII/SNPC. The spectrum of Fe/NPCHT2 exhibited three distinct kinds of FeN x sites, namely D3, D2, and D1 (Fig. 6b). The presence of D3 suggests that iron occurs in both the +2 and +3 oxidation states in the Fe/NPC-HT2 catalyst. Consequently, the presence of the embedded S atom adjusts the distribution of electric charge in the Fe center due to the difference in electronegativity between S and C. The quantitative study revealed that SA-FeIII/SNPC has a proportion of 38.74% D1 species and 61.25% D2 species, which is substantially higher than the proportions of 23.20% and 39.95% found in Fe/NPC-HT2. Through the implementation of the S regulation, they have successfully observed the change in the valence state of Fe from +2 to +3. Additionally, they have demonstrated that the ORR efficiency of SA-FeIII/SNPC has substantially improved compared to that of Fe/NPC-HT2. Further, the mass-based site density (MSDD1) was determined based on the Mossbauer data (Fig. 6c). The Mossbauer spectrum provided the highest site density value for MSDD1. The SAFeIII/SNPC had an MSDD1 value that was almost twice as high (4.16 × 1021 sites g−1) as Fe/NPC-HT2 (2.49 × 1021 sites g−1), demonstrating that the inclusion of S effectively maintained the active site numbers. XAS studies were conducted to see and analyze the electronic and local structure of the central atom, iron. Fig. 6(d) displays the Fe K-edge XANES spectrum of SA-FeIII/SNPC, along with references such as Fe/NPC-HT2, Fe foil, FePc, FeS, and Fe2O3. The pre-edge seen at about 7114 eV is attributed to the symmetrical FeN4 square planarity, as shown in Fig. 6(d) inset. In SA-FeIII/SNPC, this pre-edge moved to higher energy due to the creation of an N–S bond in the second shell surrounding the Fe atom. More precisely, the absorption edge of SAFeIII/SNPC was found to be located between the absorption edges of Fe foil and Fe2O3. This displayed that the typical oxidation state of SAFeIII/SNPC falls between 0 and +3, which is consistent with the findings of Mossbauer spectroscopy [136]. In addition, it is clear that the oxidation state of Fe/NPC-HT2 was less positive compared to SA-FeIII/SNPC. This indicates that the presence of the S element enhances the electron transfer process between the carbon support and the Fe atom. The EXAFS spectrum (Fig. 6e indicates that there is no Fe–Fe scattering channel at 2.21 Å in SA-FeIII/SNPC, unlike in Fe foil. This suggests that the Fe atoms in SA-FeIII/SNPC are distributed at the atomic level. The SA-FeIII/SNPC compound had a dominant peak at 1.53 Å, which was somewhat greater than the Fe–N peaks (1.48 Å) in FePc but shorter than the Fe–S peaks (1.8 Å) in FeS. Consequently, it was hypothesized that the Fe atom in SA-FeIII/SNPC formed bonds with N/O rather than S, which aligned with the findings from the XPS S 2p analysis. In addition, they determined the coordination environment around Fe by analyzing EXAFS spectra, as seen in Fig. 6(g and h). In addition, a wavelet transform (WT) was conducted to differentiate the backscattering route. Fig. 6(f) demonstrates that SA-FeIII/SNPC exhibited a peak with a k value of 5.3 for the Fe-N pathway, which was distinguishable from the Fe–O (Fe2O3, 8 Å−1) and Fe–Fe (Fe foil 8.3 Å−1) pathways. The XANES and Mossbauer spectra test both indicated an increase in the valence of Fe atoms due to the modulation of S. The aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-STEM) technique offers high resolution in the Angstrom range, making it a direct means to observe individual metal atoms on the carbon substrate, provided that there is a significant contrast in atomic numbers. The high-angle annular dark field-STEM (HAADF-STEM) study, which combines AC-STEM and HAADF, allows for the direct visualization of individual metal centers and even dual metal sites. HAADF-STEM can be used with electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) to provide further insights into the specific chemical composition and bonding characteristics of metal centers. This combination can aid in the understanding of the catalytic process. Overall, the in-situ characterization of ORR has shown significant advancements in recent years. As in situ technology advances, the research on electrocatalytic processes will provide more thrilling outcomes. 3 The impact of different parameters on catalytic performance 3.1 Morphology, size, and facet sensitivity of catalyst NPs The performance and stability of a catalyst in the ORR are influenced by its size, morphology, and facet sensitivity. Tuning the particle size, morphology, and active facet exposure can enhance the catalytic performance and stability. Studies suggest that reducing particle size improves electrocatalytic efficiency by elevating d-states to the Fermi level and narrowing the d-band [137,138]. The electrochemical ORR efficiency of EC tends to diminish as the size of NPs increases. The significant alteration in volume and clumping of NPs might lengthen the path of ion diffusion and impede the flow of electrons, resulting in a reduction in the ORR. Typically, the effectiveness of catalysts is heavily influenced by the size of the metal particles. Decreasing the diameters of particles can enhance the catalytic performance for many reasons. The process of dividing large quantities of materials into NPs exposes a significant number of previously internal atoms to the surfaces, where the catalytic reaction takes place. As the size of the NPs diminishes, the surface ratio increases. On the other hand, tiny particles are more prone to having dense, low-coordinated species like edges, steps, and kinks. These features are highly effective in attaining superior catalytic performance owing to their high surface-free energy. In addition, reducing the size improves the interactions between the metal and the support, perhaps causing a rearrangement of the electronic structure of the metal species and further enhancing the catalytic process. Hence, it is commonly acknowledged that decreasing the size is a highly effective method for improving atomic usage and catalytic activity. The nanoparticle catalyst's strong binding to the support and its large surface-to-volume ratio, due to its nano dimension, will increase the catalytic activity of the electrochemical reaction. Additionally, this binding will prevent the catalyst from detaching throughout the ORR tests and lengthy periods of fuel cell operations. Nanostructure design has a crucial role in determining the specific surface area and porosity of catalysts, which in turn significantly affects the activity of the ORR. Lee et al. observed that polycrystalline Au particles with a mean diameter of 8 nm displayed the best activity, attributed to structural defects, indicating that small size alone is insufficient for optimal activity [139]. In a separate investigation, Lee et al. discovered that Pd nanocubes measuring 48 nm had superior performance in a solution of methanol when compared with nanocubes of different dimensions, specifically those measuring 27 and 63 nm [140]. The activities of Pd, based on size, were arranged in the following order: 48 nm > 27 nm > 63 nm. Numerous research studies examine the impact of morphological characteristics on monometallic electrocatalysis, specifically comparing different shapes such as nanorods (NRs), nanowires (NWs), nanoparticles (NPs), nanocubes, nanobelts, nanospheres, nanoclusters (NCs), and flower-like structures. The morphology of an EC has a direct impact on the efficiency of mass/charge transfer and the overall number of catalytic active sites. Consequently, this morphology also influences the efficiency of the EC in terms of ORR. In catalyst applications, tiny NPs are often preferred because of their elevated specific surface area (SSA). Additionally, a larger ECSA and mass activity are anticipated at the same ratio. FC reactions are influenced by the structure of the crystal. Specifically, crystal facets such as (111) have a higher specific area activity compared to (100) or amorphous surfaces when it comes to the ORR. However, the reactions are less active at the edge and corner sites due to the exceptionally strong binding energy between oxygen and the surface. Particles of larger size exhibit a greater abundance of crystal facets compared to edge and corner sites, resulting in increased specific area activity. Nevertheless, the reduced ECSA leads to diminished mass activity achievable with smaller particles. The increased surface area of various ECs allows for a greater number of active sites to be exposed, therefore improving the movement of mass and electrons. This enhancement is advantageous for the performance of the ORR. Lu et al. produced Ag nanoclusters and NPs with succimer (DMSA) as a protective ligand, revealing higher specific activities for nanoclusters than NPs [141]. Erikson et al. demonstrated that Pd nanocubes outperformed bulk Pd material and nanospheres in onset, specific activity, and E 1/2. This was owing to the fact that the cubic forms possessed a greater number of active facets than the nanospheres [142]. Jin et al. utilized an electrochemical reduction technique to create Ag nanoclusters by employing single-stranded oligonucleotide sequences (ssDNA) as a template. The Ag NCs/NG composite displayed similar electrocatalytic efficiency and improved stability compared to the existing Pt/C EC. This can be attributable to the interactions among the Ag NCs, NG, and ssDNA [143]. Another crucial parameter is facet preference in ORR catalysis, with various monometallic EC showing varied facet sensitivities. This encourages adjustments to the EC synthesis to achieve more active facets. It is explained that facets, along with other sites such as edges and vertices, contribute to the overall coordination numbers, and facets with lower atomic coordination numbers allow long-term O2 binding. 3.2 Extended surface area of EC (ESAC) Extended surface area catalysts (ESACs) are characterized by large surface areas extended in two dimensions, resembling thin films. ESACs have significantly higher efficiency in the ORR than carbon-supported NP EC, particularly in acidic environments. This heightened performance is attributed to the distinctive electronic and structural features of thin films in comparison to other structures. Examples of ESACs can be included in several forms, such as single-crystalline bulk materials and polycrystalline catalyst surfaces. The significance of structural parameters such as shape, size, category, single-crystal surface alignment, and composition in affecting efficiency is highlighted by these catalysts, which serve as significant and useful model systems. Some advanced extended surface area alloy catalysts (ESAACs) reveal a textured surface featuring Pt atoms that encompass the typical bulk composition, alongside a highly coordinated “Pt-peel” that overlays a meticulously structured surface where the essential alignment of three layers varies with the bulk. The Pt-peel surface structure of Pt3Ni1 {111} and Pt3Co demonstrated a remarkable performance of 18 mA cm−2, about 3–4 times more than normal commercial Pt/C, as shown by rotating disk electrode (RDE) experiments. The order of ORR activities at 60 °C was “Pt-peel”> Pt3Co > Pt3Ni > Pt. The enhancement of electrocatalytic activity was more pronounced in HCl (0.1 M) compared to H2SO4 (0.5 M), with the peak enhancement seen for the “Pt-peel surface” on Pt3Co in HCl, which is 3–4 times superior compared to balk Pt. The configuration of Ni and Pt atoms in the top three layers of this system is influenced by variations in the d-band concerning the Fermi level of the outermost layer of Pt atoms. This configuration is anticipated to affect the sorption exposure of the hydroxyl group, thus affecting the activity of the ORR. However, there is a must to investigate how to get a viable electrocatalyst. Literature surveys indicate that nanostructured thin-film catalysts (NSTFCs) are viable electrocatalytic materials. 3.3 Metal-ion center The presence of a metal ion center has a substantial impact on the redox and electrical characteristics of TM material [144]. Among these, Fe and Co ions exhibit outstanding electrocatalytic characteristics because of their distinctive redox attributes. These active sites were recently recognized as highly effective for the ORR in PEMFCs, especially in basic environments. As a result, Co and Fe have been the main subjects of substantial research in the field of NNMEC techniques for ORR. The interaction between metals is crucial in regulating the efficiency of these materials in the ORR. Specifically, the high ionization potential of these metals is recognized as a crucial feature exerting a substantial influence on ORR performance. Notably, DFT models have revealed that Co porphyrin exhibits a significantly larger ionization potential compared to its Fe counterparts. Although the ionization potential of Fe is significantly larger than that of Co, it is important to evaluate the impact of ligands on characteristics and ORR efficiency. Typically, greater efficiency in ORR is linked to metal-ion centers that have larger ionization potentials and improved ability to bind with O2. 3.4 Nano-dimension of EC Nanocatalysts play a crucial role in advancing new energy resources, and the design of catalysts with specific unique structures is highly sought. Recent research has extensively explored various fabrication techniques for catalyst production. Efforts have also been directed towards enhancing the catalytic active site for the ORR, resulting in significant progress. However, achieving the required porosity is essential to provide a greater number of active sites and improve the ORR performance of the catalyst. Nanostructured materials hold significant importance in electrocatalysis, and current research in nanoscience and nanotechnology is particularly focused on EC fabrication. Research on doped carbon structures and porosity has become a vital part of catalyst design in the present day, to improve catalyst efficiency. Zhang et al. [145] fabricated controlled 2D WN nanosheets that are highly effective nano-EC for the ORR. In alkaline electrolytes, the EC activity of WN in ORR is influenced by the presence of potassium ions (K+). These ions played a crucial role in controlling the shape and size of nanostructures formed under the nitridation preparation and hydrothermal methods. Specifically, K+ promotes the formation of plate-like nanostructures of WO3 and two-dimensional sheets of WN. Furthermore, the WN sheets, which have been optimized to have a maximum number of exposed edge sites, provide a large number of electrocatalytic active sites that enable rapid charge conversion. Furthermore, these catalysts based on WN exhibit exceptional durability and resistance to methanol in ORR. Wang et al. [146] produced N and B co-doped carbon-based nanomaterial, which acts as a low-cost nano-electrocatalyst for ORR. Developing advanced and efficient synthesis methods for carbon nanostructures doped with both boron and nitrogen without the creation of direct covalent boron nitride is a captivating endeavor. The preparation of B and N-doped graphitic nanosheets was achieved using a straightforward process involving the utilization of iron forms. This technique allowed for the preservation of nitrogen content while simultaneously doping the B element. The resultant B and N-doped graphitic nanosheets exhibit a much higher onset potential compared to both B and N-doped graphitic carbon nanosheets individually. In addition, nanomaterials illustrate superior methanol tolerance and remarkable stability compared to commercial Pt-C EC. Kiani et al. [147] synthesized NiFe2O4 NPs with N-doped graphene to create a more efficient nano-EC for the ORR. The electrocatalytic performance of NiFe2O4 with an N-doped graphene nanohybrid is superior to that of pure NiFe2O4 and N-doped graphene. This nanohybrid promotes the desired direct 4e-reaction route during the ORR mechanism. The remarkable EC activity of the nanohybrid is attributed to the strong connection between the NiFe2O4 NPs and the N-doped graphene, as well as the network topology. 3.5 Current strategies for designing hierarchical porous structures The catalytic efficacy is contingent upon the properties of the active site and its accessibility to the reactant, which is predominantly affected by the substrate's microstructure. Hierarchical porous medium or porous material utilized as catalyst supports possess distinct attributes, such as elevated surface area, reduced density, and increased active site density. As opposed to solid substances, hierarchical porous architectures significantly enhance the specific surface area of catalysts, hence exposing active sites and promoting mass diffusion. The alteration of hierarchical porous structure can substantially influence or even change catalytic performance. Hierarchical pore structures are a category of functional nanomaterials characterized by cavities or voids of varying pore diameters contained within a specified shell. The hierarchical pore structure enhances the selectivity of catalytic processes by meticulously regulating pore size and the disparity between molecular sieve and nanopore diffusivity. Furthermore, a cascade reaction can be initiated by manipulating the spatial arrangement of the catalytic active site. Moreover, hierarchical porous architectures are often advantageous for enhancing mass transfer. They also enhance charge transfer, facilitating rapid reversible de-intercalation of ions and improving rate performance [148]. Furthermore, they can improve the structural integrity of the electrode material, thereby extending the cycle life of energy storage devices, as the extensive porous architecture and the interconnectivity of pores across various length scales can accommodate volume fluctuations as well as facilitate heat absorption and dissipation during operation [149,150]. Hierarchically structured porous substances featuring vascularized branch systems have a rich and diversified architecture resulting from the interplay of many organizational, structural, and geometric properties of pores across multiple length scales. The main thing to look at is the number of scale levels in hierarchically organized porous materials. If they are bimodal mesoporous, they can have two or three stages of pore sizes at a single scale level. If they are micro–macro, micro-meso, meso-macro, or even micro-meso-macro, they can have multiple levels of pore sizes that cover two or three-length scales. Secondly, it is acknowledged that hierarchically organized porous materials contain both bigger and smaller pores; hence, the dimensions and proportions of these pores constitute a critical design element. Moreover, pore morphology is a critical determinant, which might manifest as columnar with uniform lower and upper diameters, or as funnel-shaped with varying lower and upper diameters. Furthermore, these pores may exhibit either order or disorder. Their channels can exhibit either a centrally diverging direction or a vertical and parallel alignment. Consequently, the scientific and precise design methodologies for hierarchically organized porous materials are of paramount importance. 3.6 Construction of the hierarchically structured porous materials The templating techniques are the predominant ways for synthesizing materials with a porous hierarchy. The hierarchically organized porous medium created via templating techniques (consisting of hard and soft templating routes) possesses adjustable pore sizes and customizable pore geometries. Nevertheless, these solutions necessitate a post-template elimination step, which entails intricate procedures and demands additional resources and work. Template-free approaches, mostly associated with spontaneous formation phenomena and self-assembly processes, are considerably easier; yet, they provide challenges in control and make it arduous to forecast the shape and size of the pores owing to their inherent spontaneous nature. (1) Soft templating Soft templates often denote molecular systems characterized by variable organizational structures and restricted domain capabilities within a specific spatial range. (2) Surfactant templating A technique called surfactant templating makes a porous medium via multi-molecular aggregates (like vesicles, micelle, and liquid crystal) to guide the structure. These aggregates are made using surfactant molecules. This technique facilitates the synthesis of mesoporous materials featuring well-ordered channels and consistent pore dimensions.
