(3) Emulsion templating Emulsion templating relies on the characteristics of emulsions, utilizing the solidification or polymerization of the emulsion in the continuous phase to create materials with optimal porosity. This approach is straightforward and moderately gentle, suitable for producing hierarchically structured porous medium with meso- or macro-pore, as the size and distribution of emulsion particles may be regulated between 10 and 1000 nm. (4) Breath figure templating The breath figure (BF) route derives its name from a phenomenon in which water vapor condenses on cold surfaces, resulting in the formation of orderly, hexagonally distributed water droplets. This approach uses water droplets as templates. This is among the most efficient techniques for the large-scale production of two-dimensional organized porous structures. This method enables the utilization of star, block, and graft copolymers, alongside conjugated polymers and inorganic materials with rigid segments, to fabricate honeycomb-like ordered porous membranes with pore dimensions spanning from several hundred nm to several hundred μm. (5) Hard templating Hard templates are typically materials with somewhat inflexible structures that direct material growth by constraining spatial dimensions. In contrast to soft templating methods, hard templating techniques are more efficient in accurately regulating pore sizes owing to their robust spatial confinement effect; nonetheless, the removal of hard templates poses greater challenges. (6) Colloidal crystal templating Colloidal crystals become created through the self-assembled preparation of monodisperse microspheres with a 3D-opal structure. The colloidal crystal templating technique produces a three-dimensional ordered macroporous (3DOM) structure resembling an opal. By modifying the size of the microspheres in the templates, the dimensions of the pores can be easily changed as they are systematically organized. (7) Bio-templating The bio-templating technique employs natural biomass as a template, undergoing specialized treatment to preserve the structural integrity of biological heritage, resulting in porous materials with exacting structures. The intrinsic hierarchically porous architecture of biological materials confers numerous attributes, including a substantial specific surface area, reduced weight, and elevated permeability. A stable and regulated environment for material creation can be provided by the organism's chemical composition and unique microstructure simultaneously. In order to produce high-efficiency materials for practical commercial applications, it is necessary to use appropriate natural biological structures as templates. (8) Polymer templating Polymer foams, gels, and fibers, which are porous polymeric materials with mesoporous or macroporous structures, can be used as templates for manufacturing hierarchically structured porous materials. The distinctive benefits of porous polymers, including diverse preparation techniques, customizable pore dimensions, and modifiable surface properties, enable their use as templates that facilitate chemical reactions and serve as scaffolds for nanoparticle infiltration. (9) Template-free methods The disadvantages associated with elevated costs and laborious preparatory processes of soft and hard templating have impeded mass production for large-scale applications. Preferably, template-free techniques for the production of hierarchically organized porous medium with a broad range of pore diameters and diverse forms would be advantageous. (10) Self-formation Hierarchically organized porous materials can be synthesized successfully using the self-formation method, which is based on a spontaneous occurrence related to the chemistry of organic metal alkoxides and alkali metals. The rapid hydrolysis and condensation of metal alkoxides result in the swift release of water and alcohol molecules, which are crucial for the parallel macroporous channels creation inside the materials. (11) Sol-gel controlling The sol-gel technique is a crucial tool for regulating the chemical and physical features of materials due to its ability to organize inorganic species at the molecular level. During preparation, the capillary shrinkage force resulting from gelation will produce pore contraction and a reduction in porosity. Consequently, in practical applications, the sol-gel technology frequently necessitates integration with templating techniques. (12) Selective leaching Immiscible two-phase composites, including desirable and sacrificial phases, can serve as precursors for selective leaching, facilitating the creation of various hierarchically organized porous materials, such as metal oxides and metals. Initially, a thoroughly mixed composite is produced using various physical or chemical methods, including sintering, evaporation, and the disintegration of mixed precipitates; subsequently, the sacrificial phase is eliminated via chemical processes, resulting in a porous framework of the intended phase. 4 ECs for ORR 4.1 Non-precious metal (NPMEC) or non-noble metal (NNMEC) The high cost and limited availability of FC technology are commonly cited as major barriers to its development. As a result, researchers and scientists have extensively examined the performance of the ORR, investigating a wide range of platinum-free ECs. Several Pt-free ECs including MOs, MCs, TMNs, MONs, MSs, SACs, M-N-C, and MOFs [151–162] have been developed using NPMs because of their low cost, availability, and abundance in nature. NPMECs have undergone extensive research because of their exceptional catalytic efficiency, long-lasting nature, and cost-effectiveness. It has been shown that NPMECs exhibit greater stability in less harsh alkaline conditions. However, the attendance of an acidic electrolyte might accelerate the corrosion of NPMECs because of the abundance of H+ ions, which limits their use in such conditions. However, NPMECs have minimal disruption from methanol because of their great selectivity, which contributes to their overall performance. Lang et al. delved into metal-based catalysts for ORR, emphasizing NNMEC, such as transition metal nitrides (TMNs), transition metal carbides (TMCs), transition metal oxides (TMOs), and layered double hydroxides (LDHs) [163]. These electrocatalytic materials prevent the requirement for precious metals while exhibiting exceptional electrochemical efficiency and durability in ORR. While employing these EC in acidic electrolyte environments presents difficulties, their performance in basic electrolytes has been exceptionally noteworthy. The kinetics of the ORR are greatly improved in basic solutions compared to acidic conditions. The TMO EC is capable of reaching performance levels that are comparable to those of EC based on Pt if they are constructed with an adequate structural design. TMOs have attracted attention owing to their cost-effectiveness and controllability. Scientists have also studied the use of 2D TM hydroxides for ORR in basic environments. They have examined how these hydroxides are made and how their structure grows, with a specific focus on breaking them down into nanosheets [164,165]. In addition, metal-oxynitride materials have demonstrated very accurate ORR efficiency [166]. Cost-effective NNM catalysts have demonstrated notable improvements in the efficiency of ORR. The formation of the NNM catalyst as an ORR catalyst in PEMFCs is shown in Fig. 7 [14]. The creation of NNM catalysts has been investigated via several analyses, including Fe-based hetero-atom polymer components and cobalt pyrolysis, amongst others. The pyrolysis and impregnation preparation method, involving the networking of Fe and N, has resulted in maximal activity [167]. The nature of active sites in NNMEC still requires discussion, specifically regarding the coordination of iron with the active site and the methods used to create these active sites. It has been shown that catalyst endurance decreases with increasing potentials, and for automotive uses, catalytic efficiencies <0.6 V tend to be impracticable. Nasim et al. [168] introduced an NPMEC for ORR in the alkaline environment. The synthesized EC exhibited superb activity to 20 wt% Pt/C in KOH (0.1 M) with the E onset = 1.03 VRHE, E 1/2 = 0.89 VRHE, and J = 6.32 mA cm−2. The increased activity is ascribed to the combined impact of CoOx, FeOx, and the presence of four distinct N atoms. The ORR capability of the as-prepared catalyst was also examined in the presence of a 0.5 M concentration of methanol. The catalyst demonstrated greater resistance to methanol addition. After 10,000 cycles in a 0.1 M KOH solution, the accelerated durability test (ADT) shows that there is only 17 mV of degradation. Zhou et al. [169] developed a pH-universal ORR catalyst for use in both Zn-air batteries. Achieving a logical, hierarchical porous structure with controlled size and a specific ratio of micropores to mesopores has been accomplished. This structure is advantageous for facilitating mass transfer in the ORR. The NNMEC illustrated superb ORR performance throughout a wide pH range, with an E 1/2 = 0.91 V in alkaline electrolyte and E 1/2 = 0.76 V in acid electrolyte. The zinc-air battery had an impressive peak power density of 203 mW cm−2 and demonstrated 130 h of long-term stability, indicating excellent battery performance. Tian et al. [170] developed high-durability NNMEC toward the ORR in alkaline media. The NNMEC exhibited an E 1/2 of 0.91 V and adequate stability of 100,000 voltage cycles with 29 mV E 1/2 loss. DFT simulations have verified that the presence of vacancies near active sites can decrease the adsorption-free energy of OH* and impede the dissolution of the metal center. This leads to a substantial improvement in the kinetics and stability of the ORR. NNMEC demonstrated exceptional power density and maintained long-term stability for over 1200 h in rechargeable zinc-air batteries (ZABs). Li et al. [171] fabricated Pt-free EC (NNMEC) as a bifunctional EC toward ORR and OER activity for rechargeable zinc-air batteries (RZABs). The potential gap for this NNMEC was 0.616 V, while the E 1/2 for ORR was 0.884 V and the overvoltage for OER was 270 mV at 10 mA cm−2. The peak power density of RZAB was 203.36 mW cm−2 with a lifetime of over 550 h, even beyond the commercial Pt/C + IrO2 catalyst, which is due to the good activity of this NPMEC. Moreover, flexible RZAB with such EC shows the promising future of NPMEC in wearable energy storage devices. 4.1.1 Metal-oxide (MO) catalyst Simultaneously, complexes of MOs and carbon have demonstrated significant advancements in both durability and activity [172]. Consequently, the enhancement of electronic structure has the potential to elevate catalytic activity. MOs have recently been employed as catalyst supports for the ORR in an acidic environment. This is done by moving the D-band center to the best spot. In a study by Huang et al., a porous MnCo2O4 bifunctional EC was developed using a solvothermal preparation method, following the calcination route for ORR and OER [173]. The exceptional efficiency can be associated with the large surface area, high porosity, and tiny size of NPs, which are accurately regulated through the solvothermal method. MOs have demonstrated notable catalytic activity and durability as independent EC for the ORR in both aqueous acidic and alkaline environments. They offer several advantages, such as abundant availability, cost-effectiveness, and eco-friendliness. In contrast to carbon materials, metal oxides exhibit significantly greater corrosion resistance in electrochemical environments, attributed to their elevated oxidation states that impede electron loss. Group IV-XII TMs possess various oxidation states due to their electronic configurations. This characteristic enables them to efficiently absorb and dissociate O2 molecules on their surface, hence increasing the process of ORR. TMOs, in contrast, exhibit limited electrical conductivity and lack surface sites for oxygen adsorption. Consequently, their ORR activity in bulk form is significantly sluggish. Conductive carbon hosts can enhance the TMOs' conductivity and the electron transfer activity at the cathode contact. While carbon structure's supporting features have been presented by multiple TMOs, the main focus is on the catalytic activity of TMOs. Various research approaches have been pursued to enhance the catalytic efficiency of TMOs, such as modifying the surface, introducing dopants, forming alloys, and dispersing high amounts of N/P-hetero-atoms. Perovskite materials can be discovered in addition to their role as active ORR catalysts [174–177]. Zhang et al. [178] introduced typical post-transition metal oxides, including CoO, NiO, CuO, ZnO, and as primary constituents or supports in the domain of electrocatalysis. The catalysts demonstrated differing selectivity for the 2e− ORR, with approximate values of 36.8%, 79.4%, 82.8%, and 90.0%, respectively. The ΔG*OOH value of ZnO is closest to its ideal potential at the limiting potential, as revealed by DFT. Furthermore, with a rise in atomic number, the catalyst's efficiency in producing H2O2 by 2e− ORR showed a substantial improvement. This study offered novel perspectives on the structure and functioning of TMO materials for the formation of H2O2. Mahato et al. [179] characterized a heterostructure consisting of Cu/CuO x -Co3O4/NC-700 and found it to be a highly efficient, long-lasting, and cost-effective catalyst for the ORR. The catalyst indicated favorable ORR performance, achieving an E 1/2 of 0.81 V vs. reversible RHE and a limiting current density of 6.5 mA cm−2. The observed ORR performances were similar to those of benchmark Pt/C catalysts. The Zn-air battery, which employed an as-prepared Cu/CuO x -Co3O4/NC-700 catalyst, achieved a significant open circuit voltage (OCV = 1.41 V). The catalyst also demonstrated an exceptional specific capacity of 820 mAh gZn −1 and a great peak power density (103 mW cm−2). Nagarani et al. [180] conducted an evaluation of a hybrid EC consisting of ZnO-NiO/rGO to enhance applications related to the ORR. The hybrid catalyst was shown to possess exceptional thermal stability and a much larger specific area (395.8 m2 g−1) when compared to the bare catalysts, as determined by TGA and BET tests. By conducting a TEM investigation, researchers noticed a uniform distribution of ZnO nanorods and NiO NPs on the surface of rGO. The electrochemical investigation demonstrated that the ZnO-NiO/rGO hybrid catalyst exhibited exceptional catalytic efficiency for the ORR. It had a high limiting current density (7.1 mA cm−2), a positive onset potential (0.95 V), a low rate of H2O2 formation (less than 15%), and long-term stability. The ZnO-NiO/rGO hybrid catalyst was found to facilitate the ORR process by a highly efficient 4e− pathway, as confirmed by RDE and RRDE experiments. The ZnO-NiO/rGO hybrid catalyst showed great potential as a cost-effective catalyst for cathodes in alkaline fuel cells, without the need for costly metals. Singh et al. [181] developed a CoO x -Fe3O4/N-rGO ORR catalyst for anion-exchange membrane fuel cells (AEMFCs). This catalyst demonstrated a significant enhancement in ORR activity (130 mV@−1.5 mA cm−2) relative to pure graphene oxide (GO), with the ORR limiting current exceeding that of commercial Pt/C by 12% at 0.5 V. The better ORR performance of CoO x -Fe3O4/N-rGO was because Co, Fe, and N were spread out evenly on sheets of rGO. Also, ORR rapid stress tests showed that this material was very sturdy, which means it could be a good catalyst that lasts a long time. The CoO x -Fe3O4/N-rGO catalyst on the cathode helped us get a peak power density of 676 mW cm−2 in an operand H2-O2 AEMFC. There was the most power output per mass of cathode catalyst in a cathode catalyst that did not contain PGM. 4.1.1.1 Manganese oxides Manganese oxides, which include MnO2, Mn2O3, Mn3O4, and MnO x , have been thought of as possible alternative ORR catalysts because they are cheap, have good catalytic activity, and are structurally stable. Manganese oxides do not carry electricity well on their own, so they usually need to be mixed with carbons that do. Doping is a popular way to deal with this problem. The arrangement and interconnection of fundamental octahedral [MnO6] units result in many polymorphs of MnO2, including α-MnO2, β-MnO2, and δ-MnO2. There are many different types of structures because of two main factors that affect the change from Mn(III) to Mn(IV). One of these factors is that making crystals less perfect is a key part of getting a high catalytic activity for the ORR. As a general rule, manganese oxides have several different crystal shapes. Manganese in oxides can also have valence states of + 2, +3, and + 4, which can be used alone or together. In the ORR, all of these different valence states play a big role. Mixed valence states can make it easier for surfaces to store charges and improve their electrical and ionic properties. This, in turn, makes ORR catalysis possible. 4.1.1.2 Perovskites oxides ABO3 Perovskites have been recognized as potential replacements for conventional PGM-based catalysts in fuel cells due to their strong resistance to corrosion, efficient proton transport properties, and exceptional ionic conductivities. Among these perovskites, LaNiO3, a simple perovskite with a rhombohedral structure, has demonstrated one of the highest levels of ORR activity among similar materials. Perovskite oxides generally display significant ORR activity and moderate stability in alkali electrolytes. The characteristics of these oxides can vary extensively, associated with the composition of the A- and B-sites. Commonly the transition metal elements of the B-site can be considered as the active sites for ORR. Shao-Horn et al. [182] study results show that the extent of s*-orbital occupation and the level of covalent bonding between the oxygen and B-site metal is a vital parameter of the ORR activity of perovskites. 4.1.1.3 Spinel AB2O4 Spinel oxides with the AB2O4 formula, where A and B represent transition metals, and O represent oxygen, have shown great potential as EC for ORR in recent years. These oxides offer several advantages, including low cost, high stability, significant activity, and environmental friendliness. Furthermore, they display outstanding electrical conductivity because of the fast electron hopping between different metal valence states in O-sites. This property allows them to serve as crucial surface redox-active centers for the adsorption and activation of O2. For the enhancement of electrocatalytic efficiency, researchers have focused on finding appropriate methods to create nanostructured materials such as spheres, wires, and sheets. These materials are designed to facilitate the efficient movement of electrons and ions, thereby improving their transport paths. Compared to Pt/C, the AB2O4 oxides still indicate poor performance in ORR, which means there is a need for more enhancements. In this study, the researchers have discovered that introducing oxygen vacancies is a highly successful approach for strengthening catalytic performance. This is achieved by increasing the quantity of active sites that are exposed, adjusting the electrical characteristics of the catalysts, and improving their ability to adsorb reactants. Oxides such as cobalt oxide, cerium oxide, zirconium oxide, molybdenum oxide, and other specific oxides have generated significant attention for their potential use in catalyzing the ORR. In this context, the primary objective is to improve the performance of the ORR by enhancing conductivity and gaining a better understanding of the active sites. The main approaches to achieving high performance involve the construction of multiple TMOs, the addition of dopants, conductive carbon usage, the introduction of oxygen vacancies, and the production of crystal structures with desirable features. 4.1.2 Metal carbides (MCs) Nowadays, MCs, particularly tungsten carbides (WCs), have gained widespread use as catalyst supports for the ORR [183]. Nevertheless, the utilization of WC and other carbide alloys as effective ORR catalysts encounters obstacles due to their restricted durability under acidic electrolytes and extremely oxidizing surroundings. This impracticality can be addressed through structural modifications and alterations. To tackle these issues, investigations have focused on the impact of incorporating Tantalum (Ta) into WCs. The addition of Ta has been discovered to improve the electrocatalytic efficiency and durability in the ORR, which is linked to the formation of a Ta-W alloy. Furthermore, Ni-doped Ta-C composites, produced through sputtering methods, have been identified as effective ORR EC. These fabricated nanostructures exhibit heightened stability, attributed to the protective thin-film formation of TaO on the EC's surface. TMCs exhibit the necessary ORR activity and ascertain catalytic properties akin to Pt in various methods. TMCs, under acidic conditions, are surrounded by carbon and/or graphitic material layers, unlike TMNs [184]. WC NPs, with a mean diameter of 1.9 ± 0.9 nm, are surrounded by graphite layers and are referred to as WC@C. This configuration led to a substantial increase in activity for the 4-electron path, as it enhanced the overall catalytic conductivity and minimized the sintering of WC NPs on the ORR. The exceptional performance and stability of the system have been attributed to both the limited chemical compositions and designs. Nevertheless, the efficiency of TMC-carbon complex catalysts is influenced by many factors, including the quantity of nitrogen and the kind of graphitic shells. It is worth noting that nitrogen-doped carbon can also demonstrate substantial ORR activity. Furthermore, the composition of TMCs can be intricate. For example, WCs may consist of a mixture of WC and W2C, while iron carbide may contain both Fe and Fe3C. Hence, further comprehensive and extensive investigation is necessary to fully comprehend the functionalities of the constituent elements and the underlying cause of the heightened ORR activity of TMC-based EC. He et al. [185] prepared TMC co-doped NC as an effective bifunctional EC for HER and ORR pathways. All of the metal carbides synthesized in this study (WC/NC, V8C7/NC, and Mo2C/NC) exhibited a high level of activity in ORR. The efficacy of WC/NC at a current density of 3.0 mA cm−2 for ORR is 0.814 V (against RHE), closely approaching that of Pt/C (0.827 V), so establishing it as one of the premier transition metal carbide-based ORR catalysts in acidic electrolyte. Among them, WC/NC illustrated exceptional efficiencies, maintaining durability for 10,000 cycles without any decline in ORR activity compared with the Pt/C catalyst in an acidic electrolyte. Ingavale et al. [186] indicated a significant electrochemical efficiency of the optimized Mo2C/Fe3C-NC3 catalyst for ORR with an impressive onset potential of 1 V versus RHE, an E 1/2 of 0.89 V, and an excellent current density of about 6.2 mA cm−2. The optimized catalysts achieve a maximum power density of 142 mW cm−2 at a current density of 200 mA cm−2 in ZAB. The combination of this synergy, together with the even dispersion of Mo2C and Fe3C NPs, significantly increased the number of active catalytic sites and facilitated the diffusion of electrolytes. This significant advancement has opened up possibilities for the development of sustainable energy technologies and provides a foundation for future research on enhancing the scalability and ORR catalysts' performance. TMCs, including Fe3C, Co3C, WC, and Mo2C, encapsulated in graphitic or N-doped graphitic carbon structure, have attracted significant interest owing to their electronic structures resembling those of Pt and their pronounced ability to electrically adsorb hydrogen. Encased Fe3C NPs are believed to have a synergistic impact that boosts the activation of the outer N-doped graphitic shell. This, in turn, facilitates O2 adsorption and reduces the number of active surface carbon layers. In addition to facilitating electron transport at active sites, graphitic carbon layers can protect enclosed metal NPs from corrosion in electrolytes. This protection is crucial for ensuring the long-term stability of catalysts, especially in acidic environments. 4.1.3 Transition metal nitrides (TMNs) TMNs are gaining attention owing to their notable stability in acidic environments, positioning them as potential candidates for ORR electrocatalysis [187]. TMNs, or transition metal nitrides, are often more stable than TMs, or TMOs, because of the elevated energy levels associated with metal-nitrogen triple bonds. Moreover, their excellent corrosion resistance and remarkable conductivity make them highly appealing for ORR-EC. Nevertheless, even when considering the RDE level, the ORR efficiency of TMNs remains very poor while functioning in acidic electrolyte conditions. The addition of nickel to titanium nitride nanocrystals resulted in the formation of a binary Ti-Ni nitride, which exhibited greater ORR activity in an acidic medium compared with the original nanocrystals. Additionally, it performed similarly to commercially available Pt/C catalysts in alkaline electrolytes. The suggestion was made to use Ni doping as a means to improve the capability of Ti atoms to transfer electrons to adsorbed O2 and somewhat weaken the Ti–O bonds. Both of these factors contribute to the activity of the ORR. Catalysts based on VN and NbN, produced using the same doping approach, exhibited high potential for catalyzing the ORR in alkaline environments. Fu et al. [188] investigated hierarchical porous VN/NC/C nanocomposite for ORR. The VN/NC/C nanocomposite exhibited superior catalytic activity with an E onset of 0.87 V, a limiting current density of 4.05 mA cm−2, and excellent durability. The experimental data and DFT estimation demonstrated that the combination of NC and VN resulted in a synergistic effect, which led to the optimization of the free energies of the reaction intermediates. This optimization considerably enhanced the adsorption of O2 and reduced the potential of the rate-determining phase. The ZABs constructed with VN/NC/C nanocomposite illustrate an open circuit potential of 1.30 V, an energy density of 856.27 Wh kgZn − 1, and a large power density of 141.82 mW cm − 2. It has been established in a great number of investigations that the integrated N atoms have the potential to influence the electron distribution of the parent metal [189]. After the creation of M–N bonds, the lattice expands and the distance between metal atoms increases. This causes the metal d-band to broaden and results in a rise in the density of states (DOS) around the Fermi level. TMNs have catalytic characteristics similar to those of Pt-based metals, making them suitable as cathode catalysts in Zn-air batteries. Furthermore, TMNs possess not only the superior electrical conductivity of the original metal but also display the properties often associated with ionic crystals and covalent compounds. The presence of covalent connections gives it the characteristics of covalent compounds, such as high hardness. The exceptional ionic conductivity and superb electronic properties of TMN stem from its ionic and metallic bonding. It has recently been shown that the structure of a nitride-core and oxide-shell morphology can serve as a high-conductive catalyst for the ORR in an alkaline environment. The shape of TMNs significantly influences the ORR activity of these catalysts. For metal nitrides to maintain long-term stability, it is essential to apply an additional passivation layer. A comprehensive comprehension of the links between structure and activity is employed to fabricate TMNs with nanotube morphology. These TMNs, in contrast to TMNs with nanosheet morphology, demonstrate considerably enhanced ORR activity at the level of the whole cell. The exceptional ORR performance is ascribed to the alteration of the electronic states of the material. The fusion of TMNs with carbonaceous materials, similar to the fusion of TMOs with carbon-based materials, enhances the performance of ORR. The intense interaction between the two components in the hybrid catalyst leads to a synergistic effect. Researchers have also studied the ability of TMN NPs to perform the ORR under acidic conditions. He et al. [190] reported the creation of a dual-functional electrocatalyst for the ORR and OER, including Zn-doped Ni3FeN/N-doped graphene (Zn-Ni3FeN/NG). The incorporation of Zn as a dopant induced lattice distortion, modifying the electronic density of Ni3FeN in the peripheral areas, resulting in the creation of catalytic sites. The DFT calculations indicated that the introduction of Zn2+ ions might alter the electronic density of Ni3-FeN, resulting in a modification of the adsorption/desorption path. This modification can reduce the thermodynamic barrier for electrocatalysis. In addition to its bifunctional electrocatalytic characteristics, the Zn-Ni3FeN/NG material demonstrated acceptable electrochemical activity and durability, as well as a comparatively high overpotential of 740 mV. However, it exhibited a greater power density in comparison to the commercially available Pt/C and RuO2, which were 158 and 120 mW cm−2, respectively. Xia et al. [191] conducted a study to provide a more comprehensive understanding of the electrocatalytic efficiency of MoN/C, which was constructed by ammonia heat treatment. A current density of 0.15 mA cm−2 was at 0.40 V against NHE in a 0.5 M sulfuric acid solution. Following over 10 h of testing at this potential, no notable current degradation was noticed. The hexagonal nanostructure of MoN was found to be responsible for the O2 reduction efficiency by a 4-electron pathway, leading to the creation of water. 4.1.4 Metal oxynitrides Metallic oxynitride compounds indicate unique ORR activity, which is commonly attained through the introduction of N-doping into MOs. This procedure effectively mitigates the elevated band gap characteristic of MOs, resulting in enhanced electron-conducting characteristics for electrocatalytic applications. The incorporation of carbon in this class of material has been shown to further enhance their ORR performance. In recent studies, researchers have documented the preparation of carbon-supported zirconium oxynitride [ZrO x N y /C] EC using the pyrolysis process of ZrO2/C in the presence of NH3 [192]. It demonstrated a great ORR activity at a potential of 0.7 V vs. RHE. Furthermore, the thin films of ZrO x N y , which were prepared via a reactive sputtering path, demonstrated an onset potential of 0.8 V vs. RHE for ORR. The nanostructure of EC with the highest potential for ORR performance was found to be the crystalline Zr2ON2 phase, among the others. According to reports, adding N atoms to the oxide lattice would increase its conductivity. In the face-centered cubic structure of tungsten oxynitride (WNO), some of the oxygen atoms with a radius of 3.44 are substituted with nitrogen atoms with a radius of 3.04 in the octahedral locations. N-doping decreases the d-band gap of MOs by reducing the energy difference between electrons in the oxide. WNO materials exhibit robust electrical conductivity, exceptional corrosion resistance, high porosity, and enhanced surface wettability. Specifically, its high stability and resistance to corrosion in alkaline solutions make it a strong contender for supporting EC. Additionally, the incorporation of oxygen vacancies not only enhances the electrical conductivity but also provides additional binding sites for the metal catalysts, hence enhancing the catalytic activity. Yu et al. [193] created catalysts supported by metal oxynitride with a porous structure to improve the efficiency of the ORR. These catalysts have good conductivity and are resistant to electrochemical degradation. The catalyst, including supported nanoclusters, can increase the exposure of active surface area and enhance the density of active sites in comparison to metal NPs. The study suggests using a W0.62(N0.62O0.38) framework with a 3D organized macroporous structure to support Co nanoclusters (3DOM Co@WNO) as an ORR EC that works very well and lasts a long time (illustrated in Fig. 8 ). The presence of oxygen vacancies in WNO enhances the catalyst's electrical conductivity and electrochemical stability. Furthermore, it provides many fixed locations for the widely scattered Co nanoclusters, resulting in their enhanced stability. Moreover, the 3DOM structure design could be obtained by a controllable mass transfer pathway at the three-phase interface where the ORR reaction arises. The ORR half-wave potential of 0.85 V (vs. RHE) was obtained for the 3DOM Co@WNO catalyst in an alkaline media, and excellent stability exceeded that of the Pt/C catalyst. Theoretical simulations indicate that the robust electron-transfer interaction between Co clusters and the WNO support is crucial in enhancing the kinetics of the ORR. ZAB indicated a 185-mW cm−2 power density with a specific capacity of 740.0 mAh g−1 at 20 mA cm−2 when employed as an air cathode. The integration of conductive and durable oxynitrides, together with the construction of highly distributed nanoclusters, promotes the progress of effective and long-lasting EC for ORR [193]. 4.1.5 Metal sulfides TMSs have been extensively used as EC for ORR owing to their comprehensive electronic structure and inherent physical characteristics. TMSs utilize metal-sulfur interactions to enhance the O2 adsorption and the transfer of electrons. Metal sulfidation alters the chemical properties of TMSs and protects the metal centers from oxidation during electrocatalysis. As a result, TMSs exhibit greater stability in acidic electrolytes compared to TMOs. Typically, TMSs are produced on carbon-based structures to enhance the active surface area, the mass transfer process, electron transfer activity, structural porosity, density of active sites, and the ORR performance [194]. Mixed metal sulfide (MMS) has significantly enhanced electrochemical performance compared to monometallic sulfide, owing to their higher redox activity and superior electronic conductivity. Furthermore, MMSs exhibit enhanced electrochemical efficiency compared to MMOs, thanks to their plentiful redox chemistry and improved electronic conductivity. This is the case because MMSs exhibit more stability. Owing to their abundant redox chemistry, improved electrical conductivity, and the synergistic effects of combining two metals, mixed MMSs have emerged as desirable materials for use as electrodes in metal-air batteries (MABs), EC water splitting, and supercapacitors. Specifically, some mixed MMSs can serve as bifunctional catalysts for MABs and EC water splitting. The effectiveness of these catalysts is primarily influenced by the composition, structure, morphology, crystalline phase, and particle size of the MMS materials. Consequently, significant attention has been devoted to the development and production of materials based on MMSs, as well as the appropriate arrangement of the electrodes connected to them. Hollow nanostructures made of nickel–cobalt sulfide are a kind of nanoarchitecture that has gained significant attention due to their advantageous structural characteristics. The exceptional ionic permeability and conductivity of Ni-Co sulfide make them well-suited as core materials for supporting other electroactive materials that have low electrical conductivity. The temple-engaged approach is highly effective in fabricating Ni-Co sulfide with controlled shell thicknesses, morphologies, compositions, particle and internal void sizes, and interior complexity. The capacitance of hierarchical core-shell nanoarrays composed of Ni-Co sulfide and other capacitive materials has been enhanced. Heterostructure nanoarrays provide many electroactive sites for redox reactions, an enlarged interface between the electrode and electrolyte, a reduced distance for electrolyte diffusion, and a beneficial interaction between the core and shell components. Huang et al. [195] designed SPAN-FCNM as a multifunctional EC for overall water electrolysis and ZAB. This catalyst achieved low overpotentials (η) for the OER (η 10 = 210 mV) and HER (η 10 = 55 mV) with a minor efficiency decay of 7.5% under 100-h continuous operation in KOH at 500 mA cm−2. Furthermore, a zinc-air battery equipped with the SPAN-FCNM-coated air electrode demonstrated remarkable energy efficiency (1st cycle = 60.9%; 90th cycle = 58.9%) when subjected to a discharge/charge current density of 50 mA cm−2, which is important to industrial applications, for a duration exceeding 60 h. In the research of Cao et al. [196] NPMEC has been implemented for both ORR and OER with rapid kinetics, which is an essential component in increasing the effectiveness of the electrochemical process, especially for FC devices. The performance of a nanohybrid of cobalt sulfide and porous N-doped carbon (Co9S8/N-C) was superior to that of commercial Pt/C, which was a combination of cobalt sulfide and porous N-doped carbon. The starting point of the ORR on Co9S8/N-C is 0.05 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), which is higher than the starting points for Co9S8 + AB (−0.11 V), N-C (−0.18 V), and Co9S8 + N-C (−0.13 V). This suggests the hybrid material's superior ORR activity. The significantly reduced Tafel slopes (154 mV dec−1) of the Co9S8/N-C hybrid for both the ORR and OER indicate enhanced electrocatalytic activity of Co9S8/N-C. Li et al. [197] effectively constructed a new nanocomposite, specifically a WC/FeS/FePt/NC nanohybrid for the ORR EC. The resultant Pt-based EC exhibited a remarkable mass activity of 317 mA mg−1 Pt at 0.9 V vs. RHE, greatly exceeding the activity of Pt/C EC, which was 125 mA mg−1 Pt, by a factor of 2.5. Furthermore, improved stability in acidic electrolytes was noted for the WC/FeS/FePt/NC. This study introduces a novel way of creating high-efficiency ORR EC by the incorporation of diverse beneficial components, such as sulfides and carbides. Wang et al. [198] successfully produced distinctive hollow nanohybrid structures consisting of EC NPs that were evenly distributed and maintained within a carbon matrix. Synthesized Co9S8/NHCS composites exhibited superior ORR performance when synthesized at 900 °C, showcasing the highest ORR performance compared to other ECs. To evaluate the stability of the Co9S8/NHCS-900 catalysts, a constant voltage of 0.8 V was applied for a duration of 10,000 s in solutions of KOH (0.1 M) and HClO4 (0.1 M), whereas the catalysts were rotated at a rate of 1600 r min−1. According to research, the Co9S8/NHCS-900 catalyst's current densities toward ORR can be saved by KOH (0.1 M) and HClO4 (0.1 M) electrolytes, with a sustainability rate of 87.1% and 60%.9%, surpassing the performance of Pt/C (74.6% and 9.8%), respectively. 4.1.6 M-N-C EC Single-atom catalysts (SAC) composed of metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) materials exhibit exceptional efficacy due to their ability to expose all metal atoms to catalytic pathways. Typically, M-N-C catalysts with Fe, Co, and Ni have remarkable electrocatalytic activity and seem to be viable materials for addressing future energy issues. In addition, instead of MNPs and TM complexes, M-N-C materials possess distinct characteristics such as uniform distribution of metal atoms with low-coordination numbers, maximum utilization of atoms, and structural resemblance to naturally occurring MN4-molecules. The identification of these distinct qualities can be advantageous in identifying the activity descriptors and theoretical modeling for both homogeneous and heterogeneous electrocatalysis. These properties have led to the development of ways to design M-N-C materials that exhibit enhanced catalytic performance. Furthermore, mass transportation, density of active sites, and intrinsic features are the main factors determining ORR performance. However, the precise identification of genuine catalytic sites and their impact on the reaction, as well as the mechanism of action, remains inadequately comprehended. Researchers are employing in situ/- operand characterization approaches to get insights into these difficulties and further the improvement of energy catalysts. In catalysts with atomically scattered M-N-C structures, individual metal sites interact with donor atoms such as N, S, and O like MN4 molecular catalysts, exhibiting comparable electronic and structural features. The coordination environment and electrolyte stability of M-N-C catalysts are influenced by the valence state of the central metal. Therefore, adjusting the coordination number of the central metal atom can enhance the efficiency of M-N-C material. Zhao et al. [199] prepared FeMn(mIm)-N-C catalyst for ORR in the alkaline and acidic media. The findings demonstrated that FeMn(mIm)-N-C had exceptional ORR efficiency, with E 1/2 of 0.861 and 0.778 V in alkaline and acid environments, respectively. Additionally, the material showed remarkable long-term stability. In addition, the ZAB and PEMFCs that were put together exhibited remarkable power densities and showed potential for long-term stability when compared to 20% Pt/C. Xu et al. [200] presented atomically dispersed Zn/Co-N-C as ORR EC for alkaline FCs. This catalyst indicated excellent ORR activity with an E 1/2 of 0.938 V vs. RHE and superb stability after 50,000 cycles. Furthermore, this exceptional achievement was confirmed in practical operating circumstances of an FC, attaining an unprecedented peak power density of around 1 W cm−2, which is the highest recorded value for M-N-Cs used in AFCs. X-ray absorption spectroscopy was performed to locate the active sites and uncover mechanistic insights into catalysis. The findings revealed that the Co atom in the Co-N4 structure served as the primary catalytically active site. Specifically, one oxygenated species bonds to this site, forming an Oads-Co-N4 moiety in the ORR. Furthermore, the experimental results were effectively corroborated by theoretical investigations employing a potential-dependent microkinetic model and core-level shift calculations. These studies not only demonstrated a high degree of agreement with the experimental findings but also offered valuable insights into the O-species bonding to Co-N4 centers in ORR. 4.1.7 Single-atom EC The single-atom catalyst (SAC) has become a prominent area of research. SACs are presently regarded as highly prospective contenders for progress in energy technologies, specifically in electrocatalysis, with the capacity to diminish dependence on Pt. Replacing traditional noble metal catalysts with SACs is a pressing matter, yet it poses significant difficulties. Nevertheless, individual metal atoms tend to aggregate due to their high surface free energy. The electrocatalytic process can result in the aggregation of individual atoms, leading to the formation of a mixed phase consisting of metal NPs, single atoms, and nanoclusters. This aggregation has a significant impact on the catalytic activity and reactions. To prevent the accumulation of individual atoms, contemporary investigations have predominantly focused on SACs with low metal loadings. However, this limitation severely hinders the practical use of SACs since it reduces the number of available active sites. Therefore, it is imperative to produce SACs with high atomic loadings to boost catalytic activity and enable their practical use on a broad scale. When synthesizing SACs, it is important to maintain appropriate spacing between atoms and provide strong contact between the atomic metal centers and the supports. A complex with several coordination sites can be considered as the appropriate precursor for achieving the incorporation of a large number of single-atom active sites onto the support. Porous materials possessing significant surface areas or voids are optimal substrates capable of accommodating abundant active sites, hence achieving high metal loadings of individual atoms. Defect engineering of graphene, which may create more locations for metal atoms and heteroatoms, could be an optimal selection. Furthermore, further synthesis methodologies should be investigated to produce SACs on a wide scale. Currently, it has been proven that the hydrothermal approach and restricted pyrolysis strategy are effective in creating atomically distributed catalysts with high metal loadings. To prevent the clustering of SACs with large metal loadings, one may consider utilizing the low-temperature pyrolysis technique. Furthermore, it is possible to enhance the current synthesis methods to minimize the exposure of precursors to high-energy environments. This, in turn, can partially reduce aggregation as the metal loading increases. In addition to the clustering of individual atoms, the performance and long-term stability of SACs in real-world settings remain difficult, but are essential for widespread use in commercial applications. Many of the electrocatalysts used in the ORR in acidic environments are not sufficiently active and stable. This substantially restricts the use of SACs in PEMFCs. To address these issues, it is crucial to carefully choose appropriate metal precursors and supports that can provide robust interactions between the metal centers and supports. It is crucial to precisely control the coordination environments of metal centers in SACs. This may be accomplished by selecting appropriate single-site materials and supports, as well as employing suitable synthesis techniques (such as manipulating vacancies and structural defects) [201]. So far, it has been established that several M-N coordination structures are very advantageous for electrocatalytic processes. The M-N4 and M-N2 configurations of SACs are the most prevalent in electrocatalysis. Therefore, the addition of heteroatoms like N, O, S, P, B, and others to carbon materials can be considered an effective approach to enhance both the catalytic performance and durability. Furthermore, the addition of additional metal atoms to SACs to create atomically distributed dual sites might potentially improve the catalytic performance of SACs. This is because of the beneficial interactions between the two metal atoms, known as synergistic effects. Furthermore, the development of more effective and resilient EC can be achieved by a synergistic approach including experimental investigations and theoretical simulations. This approach can provide insights into the underlying reaction processes and the intricate connections between the catalyst's structure and its properties. For instance, analyzing the spatial arrangement and dispersion of metals in volcano plots, together with examining the alterations in Gibbs free energy during individual stages of electrochemical processes, might offer valuable insights for enhancing the efficiency and stability of SACs. Furthermore, there is currently a lack of thorough information on the catalytic processes of SACs. Advanced characterization methods including high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and XAS are highly helpful in identifying the actual active sites. Nevertheless, they are unable to see the dynamic alterations, including changes in structure and components, of active sites during electrocatalysis. This limitation somewhat hinders the ability to get a more profound understanding of intricate catalytic processes on SACs. Therefore, it is necessary to create additional in situ/operand characterization methods, since the existing ones are still insufficient to fulfill actual needs. Characterization techniques like in-situ XRS, TEM, and XAS provide valuable and dependable means to directly examine the structural features of active sites and the dynamic processes involved in electrocatalytic reactions. These techniques aid in comprehending the relationships between process, structure, and property. In terms of the current in situ/operand study, a combination of multiple XRS characterization techniques is vital because using 3D metal K-edge XANES is advantageous for obtaining valuable data about the bulk and surface of SACs. Furthermore, in-situ XAS is an invaluable characterization technique for identifying the dynamic active sites and reaction processes in electrocatalytic reactions. It provides surface-sensitive information and is advantageous for designing efficient and resilient SAC at the atomic level. Recent research reports suggest that SACs can exhibit superior performance for ORR efficiency and durability. The IL-M-SAC catalyst's electrochemical performances versus ORR are shown in Fig. 9 (a–i) [202]. Zhu and his colleagues [203] carried out a thorough evaluation of metal catalysts that scatter at the atomic level, composed of clusters and single atoms for ORR (Fig. 9j). The high stability of SACs is attributed to the robust association between single atoms and the host link's active sites. The SACs have exhibited notable catalytic efficacy, particularly in the context of Co-based SACs. Extensive research has been performed to elucidate the effective production of Co-SACs with substantial metal content employing a pyrolysis technique. An additional research endeavor resulted in the discovery of a process that defies common sense, namely the transformation of NPs of noble metal into single atoms that are thermally stable at temperatures higher than 900 °C. Various approaches were employed to investigate the atomic distribution of Pd, which unveiled the presence of a transition phase that occurs between the sintering and atomization processes of NPs within SACs. According to theoretical calculations, it has been proposed that the transformation process at elevated temperatures may be intensified, resulting in the creation of stable Pd-N4. This enhancement is associated with the capture of individual Pd atoms by defects in N-doped nanocarbons. W-N-based electrocatalytic performance [204] was improved by modifying fabrication factors such as temperature feasibility, pyrolysis atmosphere, and duration. Furthermore, it has been shown by DFT calculations and experiments that the increased catalytic efficiency of W-based SACs can be ascribed to the presence of adequate contacts between individual W atoms and OH groups, potentially resulting from the appropriate hybridization of dz 2-pz orbitals. The activity of Ni-based SACs has been assessed, where Ni-N4 sites are integrated into a three-dimensional and hierarchical carbon-based nanostructure. This nanostructure displays excellent electrocatalytic performance for ORR in a basic medium [205–207]. The catalytic activity of this NiN4-C-based nanomaterial is comparable to Pt-C catalysts. The NiN4-C catalyst consists of numerous single Ni-atom active sites, each coordinated with four N atoms, as determined by ICP-OES. It has been demonstrated through both practical and theoretical evaluations that the ORR catalyst that was produced possesses a high 4e− selectivity. Moreover, the NiN4-C EC demonstrates a high-power density (95 mW cm−2), comparable to Pt-C power density. These findings support the exploration of catalytically active sites in carbon support Ni-based EC. Simultaneously, another study reports the transformation of Ni NPs into stable. The facilitation of this transformation is associated with the existence of many flaws inside the N-doped carbon structure. A highly active catalyst composed of Ni-N4-GHSs-Fe-N4 has been produced by researchers using a self-assembly approach [208]. The present catalytic material demonstrates notable catalytic effectiveness by the dispersion of Fe and Ni ions, strategically located on both the inside and outside surfaces of hollow graphene (Gr). Recent research evaluations suggest that Ni-based SAC coordination significantly enhances ORR activity. A variety of metal-based SACs have been explored, including Ni-N2O2 nanomaterials as SACs [209,210]. The active sites in Ni-N2O2-C have garnered attention for their remarkable efficiency. In a basic electrolyte, analyses indicate that Ni-N2O2 active sites exhibit notable selectivity in the reduction of O2 to H2O2. The Ni-N2O2-C EC was prepared via a ligand-mediated pyrolysis procedure, which offers a promising approach for producing ORR catalysts on a wide scale for FCs. Researchers conducted a study that revealed the effectiveness of using a SiO2-templated strategy to generate Co-active sites that were distributed across hollow spheres based on Gr (GHS) as an ORR EC. Furthermore, enhanced ORR activity is demonstrated by cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc). Yuasa et al. [211] incorporated Co ions into polypyrrole in methanol at 120 °C to create an ORR EC based on nanocarbon that is co-doped with N and Co. This catalyst represents the coordination of Co and N4 in a pyrrole-type structure. The resulting catalyst exhibits high ORR performance in a basic environment, with further improvement observed after pyrolysis at 700 °C. The retention of closed-packed Co-N4 is ascribed to exceptional outcomes, whereas the depletion of Co-N groups at an elevated temperature (1000 °C) results in the proliferation of metallic Co, resulting in a deterioration in electrochemical efficiency. This suggests that Co-N4 moieties play a crucial role in electrocatalytic efficiency. However, EXAFS assessments offered only moderate structural evidence, leaving uncertainty about the preservation of all Co-N4 moieties during pyrolysis at elevated temperatures. Therefore, detailed analyses were conducted to reveal the Co-N x configurations using theoretical exploration and empirical findings. Recent research has produced different forms of Co-N x molecules, suggesting that the nanostructures of Co-N-C molecules stay unaltered when subjected to an applied potential [212]. The authors have put forth a straightforward method for the production of Fe-based catalysts that are atomically distributed throughout N and Fe-doped nanocarbons, resulting in the formation of five Fe-N5 active sites [213]. Furthermore, the catalyst ORR activity is modified by introducing Fe atoms through doping, providing an effective approach to creating EC that is connected to structure and activity. This strategy allows for the creation of EC with a significant number of active sites in M-N x , thereby enhancing catalytic efficiency. Various methods have been explored for fabricating noble and NNM-based SACs, relying on different metal properties. An exhaustive protocol is required for potential preparation to acquire a diverse range of SACs. Researchers have also uncovered EC that possess both dual and bimetal active sites. Yang et al. [214] produced a dual-metal SAC consisting of Fe and Cu on commercially available carbon black to enhance the efficiency of the ORR. Fe and Cu atoms were uniformly distributed on commercially available carbon black material, forming FeN4 and CuN4 sites at the atomic level.
