It exhibited a high E 1/2 of 0.926 V and displayed good stability in 0.1 M KOH. These values are significantly superior to those observed in the Fe-SAC or Cu-SAC control samples. DFT simulations demonstrated that the presence of a single Cu atom enhances the electron density of Fe sites, effectively donating electrons. This results in optimized adsorption/desorption energy for ORR intermediates, hence promoting the ORR activity of FeCu-SAC. Furthermore, a study conducted on three common commercial carbon substrates demonstrated that carbon support with elevated surface areas and a hierarchical pore structure had a positive impact on the ORR. The FeCu-SAC catalyst exhibited outstanding ORR performance and long-lasting durability, resulting in a Zn-air battery with a remarkable power density of 201.4 mW cm−2 and a high specific energy of 827.68 Wh kg−1. Shao et al. [215] discovered single sites of SnN4O in the main group that have been optimized to enhance the ORR by improving the distribution of charges. The Sn SAC that was constructed had exceptional ORR performance, with a very high E 1/2 of 0.912 V (vs. RHE) and excellent mass activity of 13.1 A mgSn −1 at 0.850 V (vs. RHE). These values beat those of commercially available Pt/C and most TM-based SACs that have been reported. Furthermore, the Sn SAC that was described exhibited remarkable stability in the ORR as a result of the robust contact between the Sn sites and the carbon support, facilitated by the presence of oxygen atoms acting as bridges. The high ORR efficiency of Sn SAC was also shown by ZAB tests conducted in both liquid and solid states, which indicates that it has a significant amount of promise for use in real-world applications. The ORR efficiency of TM-based SACs is presented and compared in Table 1 [216–229]. The process of designing SACs at the molecular level has been briefly explained, providing a clear understanding of the coordination structure of metal centers. Recent research in the field of SAC-based catalysis has focused on improving catalytic efficiency by manipulating the amount of metal used. The primary objective of modifying the structure and morphology of SAC-based EC is to enhance their efficacy in mass transfer. Optimizing the porosity and density of active sites in SACs can enhance their catalytic efficiency. Despite the relatively lower activity of SACs compared to precious metal EC, it is imperative to do additional research and develop strategic design and fabrication approaches for SACs with minimal metal loading to prevent the buildup of NPs [230]. SACs present a cost-effective alternative with equal catalytic efficacy for the ORR. The first issue for SACs is their operating durability in PEMFC settings. This work examines contemporary ways of enhancing the catalytic activity of SACs, consisting of augmenting active site density, metal center coordination optimization, and designing porous substrates. Although SACs have demonstrated remarkable performance in controlled laboratory environments and during MEAs, their durability in the rigorous circumstances of functioning PEMFCs creates a significant worry. Several difficulties, such as metal dissolution, active site poisoning, and corrosion, pose considerable obstacles to the lifetime and reliability of these ECs. 4.1.7.1 Improvement strategies for activity of SACs To improve the catalytic characteristics of SACs, researchers have utilized various methodologies aimed at altering the electronic structure, geometry, and morphology of the catalysts. 4.1.7.2 Structure and active site density engineering Growth of the M-N4 active site numbers and developing a support with a highly porous structure are essential design elements to optimize catalytic activity. The alteration of pore architecture and the meticulous design of active sites are essential for enhancing catalytic efficacy. The pore structure optimization enhances the active site approachability and improves reactant molecule diffusion efficiency; hence, it expedites catalytic processes. Not only does changing the pore structure mean changing the pore size, but it also means making the pore shape and network work best for the reaction in question. The accurate formation of active sites necessitates the regulation of atomic-scale architecture on the surface of the EC. Using meticulous design and preparation, particular types of active sites, like metal clusters, single-atom sites, or uniquely structured metal oxides, can be included on the surface of the EC. You can change these active sites' electrical properties, geometric shapes, and chemical environments to fit the needs of the catalytic process. This lets you precisely control reaction paths and product selectivity. 4.1.7.3 Modulating the coordination environment By changing the number and types of ligand atoms, which is called “local coordination manipulation”, the electronic structure of the metal center is affected. This includes the electron density and d-orbital occupancy. This control can change how well the metal center can bind reactants and the activation energy. It can also create active sites with certain geometric shapes that may be better for the transition states of some reactions. This lowers the reaction energy barrier and improves the speed and activity of the reaction. The new way to boost ORR activity is different from the old way of adding heteroatoms to the carbon matrix plane. It focuses on improving the coordination sphere of intrinsic M-N x active sites by adding axial ligands like chlorine, sulfur, and oxygen. 4.1.7.4 Synergistic impacts of single atoms and clusters/particles The usage of NPs, clusters, and single atoms on carbon supports to function synergistically demonstrates significant potential for enhancing ORR activity. The clusters facilitate electron transport at the M-N4 site, enhance O2 activation, optimize *OOH adsorption at the metal's active site, and accelerate the ORR. 4.1.7.5 Regulating the spin state of metal atoms The spin state of metal atoms can affect the electron occupancy of their d-orbitals, thereby altering the electronic density at the metal core. An elevated spin state often indicates an increased quantity of unpaired electrons, which might enhance the interaction between the reactants and the metal core and hence augment catalytic activity. Changes in spin states can adjust the adsorption capacity of the metal center for crucial intermediates in the ORR. A higher spin state generally enhances the adsorption of oxygen molecules, thereby promoting the oxygen reduction process. Furthermore, varying spin states can enhance reaction routes and augment catalytic selectivity. 4.1.7.6 Improvement strategies for stability of SACs The stability of SACs for the ORR is a pivotal concern in PEMFCs, and these catalysts typically rely on M-N-C architectures. However, they lose their effectiveness quickly and aren't stable enough for real-world use. This is mostly because of carbon oxidation, metal dissolution, Fenton reactions, and active site poisoning, all of which often work together to make FC catalysts less effective in real-world settings. Demetallization is a critical aspect influencing the durability of SACs within the operation of PEMFCs. Potential variations may cause the detachment and dissolution of metal active sites in elevated potential conditions, thereby diminishing catalyst effectiveness. This dissolution process is generally linked to anodic corrosion within electrochemical processes, which is more probable during start-up and shut-down operations. Specifically, for the highly active Fe-N x centers, iron ions may leach from the metallic iron phase. While this leaching may not instantaneously lead to a decline in catalytic activity, the substantial release of these ions can initiate the Fenton reaction, generating harmful reactive oxygen species that intensify the oxidation of the carbon support and hasten the deterioration of the fuel cell. Enhancing the durability of FCs necessitates the identification of more stable carbon support materials, EC structure optimization, and the regulation of the EC manufacturing process. 4.1.7.7 Strengthening metal–N bonds The intensity of the contact between support and metal atoms is widely recognized as a crucial element in the demetallization mechanism, and enhancing the link between nitrogen and metal can increase the resistance to metal leaching. 4.1.7.8 Alternative Fe-free catalysts The addition of iron ions can modify the decomposition pathway of H2O2, resulting in an increased production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) rather than direct degradation into water and oxygen. The ROS, due to their potent oxidative capability, can target and impair the active sites or carbon matrix of the catalyst, resulting in diminished catalyst efficacy or deactivation. Conversely, other TMs including zinc, copper, cobalt, and manganese do not demonstrate the same pronounced catalytic activity in the Fenton reaction as iron. Thus, it is expected that M-N-C ECs utilizing these Fe-free metal sites will diminish the frequency of the Fenton reaction, thus improving the catalyst's durability. The use of Fe-free metals in catalyst construction is expected to reduce degradation from the Fenton reaction. Nonetheless, the inherent ORR activities of these ECs are generally inferior to that of Fe SACs, thereby constraining their applicability. Increasing the number of M-N x sites is a suitable manner to make them more catalytic because intrinsic activity is calculated by multiplying specific activity by turnover frequency. 4.1.7.9 Eliminating H2O2/ROS H2O2 and ROS can induce significant corrosion of carbon substrates and degrade the active sites of catalysts, leading to a reduction in catalytic efficacy·H2O2 is a principal generator of ROS; thus, reducing its generation or eliminating existing H2O2 is essential for limiting ROS damage. Using compounds based on platinum and cerium is a quick and effective way to get rid of harmful substances. It helps break down H2O2 and ROS into less harmful or harmless substances like H2O and O2. This technique prevents the erosion of the carbon material and catalyst active centers, preserves its catalytic activity, and prolongs its service life, thereby significantly boosting its stability and efficiency. 4.1.7.10 The anchoring mechanisms of SACs on the support substrate The instability of individual atoms leads to their tendency to aggregate into clusters or NPs, thereby minimizing their surface free energy, which can undermine the benefits of their great catalytic activity in SAC configurations. Consequently, the formulation of the stabilizing method is crucial to preserve the metal atoms' dispersion, thereby sustaining their elevated activity for catalytic reactions. At the atomic level, it is very hard to stabilize precursors like mononuclear metal complexes on carrier surfaces. Stabilizing ligands being removed from highly scattered mononuclear metal complexes leads to atom aggregation through the post-treatment method. Lowering the load of single metal atoms and choosing carriers with larger specific surface areas is one of the effective and best ways to avoid this problem. Using phosphorus, nitrogen, and sulfur atoms is another way to do it. They create the right coordination environment for monometallic complexes to attach and stick to the carrier surface. This method emphasizes preserving the robust connection between metal and coordination sites on the carriers throughout the formation method. The use of metal nanoparticle precursors is an alternative approach; nevertheless, strong metal–metal bonding limits these endeavors. To disrupt the metal–metal bonds and achieve atomically dispersed metal groups affixed to carriers without aggregation, an appropriate energy source is required. To address this issue, it is essential to establish coordination sites that can efficiently capture the dispersed metal species by forming robust links between the metal atoms and the carriers. The techniques encompass impregnation, co-precipitation, one-pot pyrolysis, step reduction, organometallic complexation, atomic layer deposition (ALD), and mass-separated soft landing. In the fabrication of SAC, many organic materials, especially polymers, have been employed as synthetic templates, protective agents, encapsulating agents, and catalyst carriers across multiple fabrication techniques. Numerous polymers are appropriate for the incorporation of supplementary active sites owing to their precisely specified porosity, adaptable tunability, elevated surface area, and diverse functional groups. Moreover, polymers may function as surfactants to modulate the crystallization of the desired catalyst. Polymers containing N-atoms are advantageous for dispersing active single atoms without aggregation and modifying charge distribution to enhance catalytic activity. Heteroatoms possessing lone electron pairs, like nitrogen, are typically prevalent in polymers or their derivatives. These heteroatoms can stabilize individual metal atoms through robust coordination interactions. The coordination environment of the solitary electron pair can increase the average adsorption distance between individual metal precursors and the polymer matrix, effectively inhibiting agglomeration in the pyrolysis process and promoting the formation of SACs. In this context, polymers containing nitrogen groups are extensively utilized to fabricate SACs. Due to the robust interaction between carriers and metal atoms, they exhibit superior intrinsic catalytic selectivity and activity compared to traditional catalysts for the ORR, OER, and other processes. Despite the significant promise of SACs in practical applications such as the hydrogen evaluation reaction (HER), OER, ORR, and CO2RR, their advancement is hindered by low single-atom loading, inadequate chemical and thermal stability, and the constraints of catalytic processes. Typically, (1) the metal–metal interaction surpasses the metal-carrier interaction in single-metal catalysts, allowing individual atoms to readily migrate and amalgamate to create metal clusters and NPs under practical reaction conditions; (2) single atoms can also induce self-agglomeration and cluster formation due to the elevated surface free energy in fabrication environments and during catalytic cycling, both of which may result in catalyst deactivation. The fundamental factor in stabilizing SAC active species is to create robust connections between the individual atoms and their supports. This robust connection is crucial in preventing solitary metal atoms from clustering, hence facilitating the formation of stable and well-dispersed SACs. The interaction happens because electrons are moved around between the single atom and the carrier. This has a big effect on the atom's electronic structure and its ability to catalyze reactions. Polymers are important in many synthetic methods because they act as carrier precursors, microstructure templates, inhibitors to limit the size of metallic particles, and protective agents for SACs. Polymers are the best choice for carriers because their shapes and structures can be changed chemically or physically to make them more porous, increase their surface area, and keep them chemically stable. Polymer carriers play an important role in keeping atoms in place on their surface by connecting with metal atoms through their many functional groups. Metal atoms can become immobile, smaller, or more limited during the synthesis process if the carrier precursors have flaws or empty spaces. To stop single metal atoms from sticking together when there are more of them, two theoretical requirements have been found: increasing the carrier surface area and making it easier for the metal atoms to stick to the carrier surfaces. (1) Mass-separated soft-landing method The mass-separated soft-landing method uses a high-frequency laser evaporation source to turn metal atoms into vapor. Then, a mass spectrometer is employed to control the deposition of the vapor, creating metal particles on the carrier surface that are of different sizes and weights. (2) Atomic layer deposition method (ALD) ALD transpires when individual metal atoms are deposited onto a carrier's surface with atomic-level accuracy. A precisely defined catalyst can be systematically fabricated at the atomic level by ALD, owing to its distinctive self-limiting surface property, which facilitates the conformal deposition of catalytic materials on the high surface area of substrates. (3) One-pot pyrolysis method The one-pot pyrolysis technique has been devised to synthesize SACs with elevated loading capacity. Stable SAC can be produced by separating isolated metal species during high-temperature processing due to fractured metal–metal or metal-O-metal connections that improve interactions between the metal and support. (4) Co-precipitation method The technique of co-precipitation facilitates the fabrication of supported metal catalysts with homogenous dispersions of multiple active components concurrently. The properties of catalysts produced via co-precipitation are influenced by several aspects, such as temperature, the base solution pH, aging duration, efficient mixing, the sequence and rate of component solution addition, and the quantity and distribution of defects on the substrate. (5) Impregnation method In a standard synthesis technique, the carrier is infused with a solution with an active component (metal salt). The active component is progressively adsorbed onto the carrier surface or confined within the pore structure following the carrier's interaction with the solution. The solution is subsequently filtered or dried to eliminate the surplus solution. The resultant solid is dried, calcined, and activated to yield the desired catalyst. The dispersion of metal is contingent upon the properties of the anchoring sites, which arise from interactions between the precursor and the carrier. (6) Organometallic complex approach A metal in a molecular complex with a certain structure can coordinate with a functional group on the carrier surface. This method can precisely place and quantify metal atoms. The manufacturing cost is a crucial determinant for the practical utilization of non-PGM catalysts. A cost comparison of the leading catalysts documented in this domain, as illustrated in Table 2 , will offer a more lucid understanding of their economic viability. 4.1.8 Dual-atom catalysts (DACs) To surpass the constraints of single-atom catalysts, dual-atom catalysts (DACs), characterized by isolated pairs of metal atoms scattered on a carbon framework as active sites, have lately been proposed and garnered significant interest in a brief period. DACs possess atomically scattered active sites and demonstrate comparable benefits to SACs in terms of the optimal performance of the metal sites. Furthermore, DACs feature two proximate metal atoms as the active center, which may lead to novel catalytic mechanisms and significantly enhanced structural adaptability in comparison to SACs. The chemical interaction between two neighboring metal atoms generates a unique electronic structure for each atom, diverging from their single-atom forms, potentially augmenting intrinsic electrocatalytic activity and optimizing ORR/OER performance. These advantages render DACs intriguing candidates for high-efficiency oxygen electrocatalysis, surpassing SACs. The isolated metal atom pairs in DACs are typically considered the active sites for oxygen electrocatalysis. In contrast to SACs, the distinctive architecture of DACs presents novel prospects for oxygen electrocatalysis. Initially, each pair of metal atoms in DACs offers two potential locations for the adsorption of oxygen intermediates, potentially introducing new reaction mechanisms to achieve reduced reaction energy barriers. DACs also have short-range contacts (1–5 Å) between metal atoms that create a unique electronic structure of the active sites. These contacts can be direct metal–metal bonds or indirect inductive M1–N/C–M2 interactions. The active sites in DACs have properties that make them better at electrocatalysis than their SAC counterparts. The inherent advantages of DACs are acknowledged from three distinct perspectives: the modulation mechanism, the bifunction mechanism, and the collaboration mechanism. 4.1.9 Advantages of DACs (1) The modulation mechanism The modulation process pertains to electronic modulation between one metal atom and an adjacent metal atom, enhancing the inherent activity of the former, which acts as the true active center. In this scenario, just one atom in the pair acts as the active center that directly interacts with the intermediates of the ORR/OER, while the other atom behaves as an ambient atom that modulates its electronic structure without directly adsorbing the intermediates. The adsorption characteristics of the oxygen intermediates at the active site can be adjusted in comparison to its SAC equivalent, hence potentially enhancing intrinsic activity. (2) The cooperation mechanism The cooperative process, namely the cooperative adsorption of oxygen intermediates on the two neighboring metal atoms of DACs, is believed to potentially disrupt scaling relations and surpass the theoretical upper limit of electrocatalytic activity. The scaling relations delineate the association between the adsorption energy of various oxygen species on designated electrocatalytic sites. The adsorption energies of various oxygen intermediates are consistently linearly correlated, provided the adsorbed atoms are the same. An increase in the adsorption energy of one intermediary at a particular catalytic site correlates with an increase in the adsorption energy of other intermediates. Consequently, in oxygen electrocatalysis involving several steps, the scaling relations link the free energy change (ΔG) of each step in ORR with OER, thereby inhibiting independent regulation by the design of active sites. Consequently, the total overpotential must guarantee ΔG < 0 for all phases, reflecting the maximum threshold of electrocatalytic activity for standard single-atom sites. Fortunately, the dual-atom locations in DACs can disrupt this link through a cooperative method. Diverse oxygen intermediates may be adsorbed onto various metal atoms or establish distinct adsorption patterns. Consequently, following the collaboration mechanism, the electrocatalytic activity of DACs is not limited by the aforementioned scaling laws. (3) The bifunctional mechanism The two neighboring metal atoms in DACs can independently electrocatalyze the ORR and OER, resulting in bifunctional electrocatalytic activity, encapsulated in the bifunction mechanism. Bifunctional electrocatalytic activity denotes an EC capable of facilitating both the ORR and OER, a characteristic essential for ensuring high energy efficiency in rechargeable metal-air batteries. Due to the differing reaction processes and rate-determining steps of the two reactions in most instances, EC featuring multiple active sites is typically regarded as providing optimal adsorption characteristics for the oxygen intermediates in OER and ORR, respectively. In the DACs, ORR and OER can be facilitated by two proximate metal atoms, with the electronic interactions between the metal pair potentially enhancing the OER/ORR activity relative to SAC arrangements. (4) Applications of DACs The significant influence of DACs transcends their direct applications, including HER, OER, and ORR, affecting the fundamental aspects of catalytic science and materials engineering. The capacity to optimize electrical and geometric characteristics via bimetallic combinations not only indicates an enhancement in catalyst efficacy but also denotes a transition towards more customizable and versatile catalytic systems. (5) DACs for HER The application of DACs in HER markedly increases catalytic research, providing improved efficiency. By utilizing the synergistic interactions between two metal atoms in a singular catalytic system, these DACs offer an innovative method for enhancing the electrocatalytic process, including atomic-level localized electric fields. This technique enhances the kinetics of hydrogen production and paves the way for the development of energy-efficient and sustainable hydrogen generation systems. The importance of atomic-scale local electric fields and the reorientation of water molecules within DACs is vital in the context of bimetallic catalysts for HER. The fundamental mechanism involves the purposeful alteration of the water structure at the electrode–electrolyte interface to enhance HER efficiency. (6) DACs for OER The utilization of DACs in OER represents a significant advancement in EC, especially in water electrolysis and renewable energy harvesting. Adding more bimetallic elements makes electrochemical dynamics better by changing the electronic structure and helping water molecules adsorb and react in the best way possible. These DACs employ a sophisticated method to modify the reaction environment by lowering energy barriers and fine-tuning the adsorption energies of intermediates, thus enhancing and expediting the oxygen evolution process. (7) DACs for ORR DACs are pivotal in enhancing the kinetics and performance of the ORR, which is vital for electrochemical energy devices such as FCs. Conventional ORR catalysts frequently have sluggish kinetics because of rigid scaling relationships. Nonetheless, DACs, recognized for their superior atomic efficiency, selectivity, and durability, provide unique solutions by overcoming these limitations, hence improving ORR efficiency. The distinctive synergistic impact in these bimetallic systems enhances adsorption-desorption dynamics, greatly improving the electrocatalytic process. DACs facilitate a more effective 4-electron reduction path, essential for enhancing the ORR rate and selectivity while providing superior durability compared to traditional monoatomic catalysts. The advancement of highly selective four-electron reaction pathways demonstrates the superior catalytic capability of DACs in efficiently facilitating ORR reactions, hence improving both kinetics and selectivity. It's important to control the complex electronic structures and interactions between sites in these catalysts to create the best electronic environment at catalytic sites. This has a big impact on ORR performance by changing the way reactions work and increasing catalytic activity. (8) DACs for CO2RR There are two main ways they work: the “Bridge” adsorption mode improves the adsorption and transfer of intermediates, and the “Intermediate Auxiliary Mechanism” keeps the stable conversion intermediates for CO2. These mechanisms jointly enhance the catalytic process, rendering DACs indispensable for sustainable CO2 conversion technologies. 4.1.10 EC derived from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) MOFs, or Metal-Organic Frameworks, have the potential to create more intricate catalysts through the use of different metal ions or clusters, organic connections, and a fast production method. MOFs show great promise as catalysts for ORR applications. The carbonization technique is straightforward and results in a metal that has a significant surface area and is doped with heteroatoms, which enhances its functionality. The MOF bimetal exhibits a minimal over-potential. The wide-ranging metal valence coordinated aromatic hydrocarbon sites, and atomic defects of this material make it highly favorable for ORR applications since they provide static sites. Recent studies have demonstrated that MOFs composed of metal ions and polyfunctional organic ligands act as ideal sacrificial templates for the controlled thermal degradation of various NPCs, including metal/metal oxide-decorated porosity, porous carbons, and heteroatom-doped porous carbons. When developing MOFs, it is important to fulfill the following conditions: (1) absence of any structure-directing agent; (2) expectation of specific structure formation based on metal–ligand chemistry, with the ability to explain variations in synthesis by creating different morphologies; (3) initiation of the reaction through reversible framework formation; (4) maintaining a consistent composition of the organic linker during the transesterification reaction. The MOF template generated carbon-based materials with notable characteristics such as a high-specific surface area, readily functionalized heteroatoms, and adjustable porosity, beyond the capabilities of traditional hard- or soft-template procedures. Many studies have been conducted to create diverse MOF-templated NPCs using multiple MOF templates and temperatures, as well as additional precursors, pyrolysis, and post-synthetic functionalization. These efforts have been driven by the numerous benefits associated with these approaches. Porous composite materials are generated by the combination of organic ligands and metal ions in MOFs, which possess expansive surface areas and customizable porosities. These materials are well-suited for energy and environmental applications, particularly in the context of batteries. MOFs are particularly suitable for usage as anode materials in lithium-ion batteries due to their ability to provide porosity (channels), organic ligands, redox metal ions, and electrolyte ion transport. Furthermore, porous, crystalline formations contain metal ions and a network of metal clusters, which can be two- or three-dimensional. Fang et al. [231] added Fe/dicyandiamide to Co-MOF to greatly improve its ORR/OER bifunctional electrocatalytic activity. FeCo@CNTs-60 catalyst had an onset potential of 1.04 V for ORR in an alkaline medium, which is close to the commercial Pt/C (40 wt% Pt) of 1.05 V. The initiation potential in a quasi-neutral solution was higher at 1.02 V compared to the Pt/C electrode at 0.99 V. Furthermore, FeCo@CNTs-60 demonstrated a minimal potential difference of 0.81 V between the potentials for OER and ORR. The ZABs, which were made using the sample as the electrocatalyst for the air electrode, showed greater peak power density and stability compared to Pt/C. Additionally, the rechargeable batteries demonstrated excellent stability when cycling discharge/charge at 5 and 10 mA cm−2. Specifically, the battery containing FeCo@CNTs-60 was subjected to a continuous cycle of charging and discharging for over 1300 h. This very long-term test was done at a current density of 5 mA cm−2. Recently published studies indicate that MOFs are present as in-situ molded precursors of porous carbon [232,233]. Studies on the impact of different porous carbon host materials on the electrocatalytic activity have revealed that an EC sustained by a Zn(II)-based MOF (ZIF-8) has 2.6 times greater ORR performance compared to EC sustained by black pearls. The improved catalytic efficiency of the EC developed from ZIF-8 can be related to its porous framework, which has a greater surface area. The active sites in the micropores play a role in this improved performance. Nowadays, researchers have successfully created EC by utilizing MOFs with core-shell nanostructures. One example is the Fe/Fe3C@C catalyst, which has demonstrated exceptional efficiency in the ORR [234]. During this procedure, scientists successfully manipulated the size and distribution of implanted NPs to increase their effectiveness. The combination of the electric conductivity and porous nanostructure enables efficient electron and mass transport to occur simultaneously. Carboxylic ligands and macrocycle ligands containing N atoms are two important ligands for the classification of MOFs [235]. Previous research has demonstrated the successful utilization of MOFs in catalyzing the ORR in PEMFCs, highlighting their obvious benefits. The zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) is the most commonly used material in the ORR process [236]. The ZIF series materials, which possess tetrahedral nanostructures, have been found to exhibit remarkable thermal and chemical stability, as well as enduring porosity. Wang et al. conducted a study where they reported the use of a carbon catalyst doped with N and S. This catalyst was generated from a MOF employing a ZIF-8 precursor. The results demonstrate that the nanocarbon material, doped with both N and S, exhibits excellent catalytic efficiency and long-term stability for the ORR in basic conditions, surpassing that of Pt/C. The N and S co-doped carbon exhibits a large specific surface area and appropriate porosity, which is beneficial for efficient mass movement and facilitates the ORR. The presence of coupled dopants enhances the reactivity of carbon active sites, leading to superior performance compared to carbon that is only doped with S or N individually. The EC is evenly dispersed at the bottom of a ceramic vessel, located in the middle of a tube, and exposed to precise gas and temperature conditions. A mixture of helium and H2 gas is introduced into the system to reduce the sample. MCs have recently seen widespread use as EC supports for the ORR in PEMFCs. RGO is gaining attention as a promising candidate for catalytic support due to its excellent electrical conductivity and good durability. Nagarani et al. [253] examined the electrochemical properties of chemically reduced graphene oxides (C-rGO) in ORR. The catalytic activity of the C-rGO was greatly improved compared to the beginning GO when it came to the ORR in alkaline solutions. The thermal characteristics of C-rGO exhibited excellent thermal stability, whereas the presence of structural flaws in C-rGO was verified using Raman analysis. The investigation of electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) indicated that C-rGO has a higher electron transport capacity compared to GO. The C-rGO catalysts exhibited an enhanced onset potential of 0.82 V, a reduced Tafel slope, and a current density of −5.6 × 10−4 mA cm−2 compared to GO. This may be attributed to the removal of the majority of functional groups by chemical reductions. The evidence indicated that the catalyst operates via a four-electron ORR pathway, as demonstrated by the increased electron transfer numbers (3.8 at a potential of −0.63 V) seen in the C-rGO. Wang et al. [254] devised a technique to simultaneously control the surface micro-morphology and construct the N-doped graphene-based nanosheets via subjecting chitin and GO to annealing. The researchers discovered that the annealing temperature played a crucial role in determining the micro-morphology and nitrogen-doping characteristics of the graphene matrix. By optimizing the annealing temperature, they were able to successfully produce 2D multi-wrinkled graphene (CS-rGO-600) with abundant active nitrogen species and moderate defects. When employed as an environmentally friendly electrocatalyst for ORR, CS-rGO-600 demonstrated exceptional performance, characterized by enhanced electrode activity and durability, as well as a greater output power density in fuel cell systems, in comparison to Pt/C. These factors might be related to the fact that the suitable annealing treatment not only promoted the enrichment of exogenous nitrogen and oriented conversion but also facilitated the building of the microstructure. The enhanced ORR performance in the fuel cell corresponds to the synergistic effects resulting from the combination of a multi-wrinkled 2D structure and active sites in the CS-rGO-600 material. Sun et al. [255] described a straightforward hydrothermal technique for preparing S, N dual-element doped reduced graphene oxide (S, N-rGO) for ORR. The process involved employing graphene oxide as the carbon source and thiourea as both the sulfur-nitrogen source and reducing agent. Heteroatom doping substantially boosted the performance of the ORR by increasing the number of active sites on the edges of defects, introducing additional sulfur and nitrogen active sites, and adjusting the electronic structure of rGO. The catalyst with a loading of 0.05-S and N-rGO had the highest activity for the ORR in alkaline circumstances, with an onset potential of 0.793 V versus RHE. It also exhibited excellent stability and resistance to methanol tolerance. The computed electron transfer number, around 3.1 ± 0.1, indicates that both two-electron and four-electron events took place on the catalyst. Several other carbon nanomaterials, including gauze, nanowires, and supported metal NPs, are equally efficient for catalysis, offering a straightforward approach for energy applications. It is important to take into account how the interaction between metal and support elements affects the formation of solid carbon compounds. The primary difficulty in developing an EC with support is achieving a homogeneous and evenly distributed arrangement of metal NPs on the material used for support. Various synthesis approaches can be employed to present NPs on the supportive surface. An appropriate supporting medium can give positive outcomes in enhancing the growth of nano-fiber characteristics. Scientists are currently studying EC produced from biomass for ORR. These ECs are economical and show improved electrochemical efficiency in neutral, acidic, and basic environments, which can be attributed to hetero-catalysis [256]. The VN QDs, which are plentiful and range in size from 3 to 6 nm, have unique structural features. These features include a large surface area and multiple levels of pores, which contain noticeable flaws that operate as active sites. Recently, various carbon nanostructures, including fullerenes, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene (Gr) sheets, and graphite nanoplatelets, which possess distinct molecular compositions and optoelectronic characteristics, are now recognized as promising options for the advancement of carbon-based catalysts with improved ORR performance within PEMFCs. In addition to their use in catalysis, CNTs have attracted significant attention for a range of applications, including field emission, H2 storage, heterogeneous catalysis, and superconductivity. Chen et al. [257] developed a two-compartment bio-electro-Fenton system, known as a microbial fuel cell (MFC)-Fenton, with a biological anode and a Fenton cathode. The cathode was made of carbon nanotubes supported on carbon brushes (OCNT-80/CB) that had abundant oxygen-containing functional groups, serving as a metal-free catalyst. The findings indicated that the presence of CO in the cathode effectively trapped oxygen from the atmosphere. This trapped oxygen was then used in situ by the electrons generated at the anode to synthesize H2O2 through a 2-electron (2e− ORR) path. Furthermore, ·OH was generated during the activation of H2O2, leading to the effective degradation of tetracycline (TC) in the cathode chamber. This work overcomes the constraints of limited pH adaptation and the subsequent environmental damage resulting from metal breakdown. The OCNT-80/CB demonstrated a significant improvement in maximum power density by 79.4% compared to the CB control, owing to the high conductivity, lifetime stability, and beneficial characteristics of the oxygen-containing functional group active centers. This study shows that meticulous structural design of the cathode can enhance the performance of the electrode. The use of MFC-Fenton can serve as a competitive method to simultaneously improve the treatment of wastewater and recover energy. Qu et al. [258] reported a hybrid catalyst consisting of metal-free graphitic carbon nitride and carbon nanotubes (g-C3N4/CNT) that can enhance the production of H2O2 through π–π interaction. This catalyst achieved nearly perfect (97%) H2O2 production at 0.57 V, with a high selectivity of over 92% across a wide potential range from 0.6 to 0 V. Carbon compounds like acetylene black and super P, which have poor contact with g-C3N4, exhibited a significant decrease in H2O2 generation. This suggests that the π-π interaction plays a crucial role. Electron transfer kinetics studies, together with density functional theory calculations, demonstrated that the combination of g-C3N4 and CNT resulted in a synergistic effect that promoted electron transfer and O2 activation between the two materials. This, in turn, led to an improved performance in the formation of H2O2. This study presented an additional method for producing H2O2 from ORR, which does not need the introduction of oxygenated groups or heteroatom doping into carbon materials. Li et al. [259] synthesized a catalyst for ORR by pyrolyzing urea with sulfur and nitrogen co-doping on carbon nanotubes (S/N/CNT). The findings demonstrated that the S/N co-doping technique effectively altered the charge distribution of carbon nanotubes, resulting in the generation of more active sites and enhancing the catalytic activity of the ORR. In a 0.1 M KOH solution, S/N/CNT's onset potential and E 1/2 of S/N/CNT in a 0.1 M KOH solution were 1.04 V and 822 mV, respectively. These values were comparable to those of Pt/C, which had an onset potential of 1.04 V and an E 1/2 of 815 mV. The S/N/CNT system followed a conventional 4-electron reaction mechanism, with an electron transfer number ranging from 3.88 to 3.91 between 0.2 V and 0.8 V. Additionally, it exhibited excellent tolerance to methanol. The S/N/CNT-based ZABs exhibited a greater galvanostatic discharge capacity than Pt/C-based ZABs and indicated good stability in 6 M KOH and 0.2 M Zn(OAc)2 alkaline electrolytes. The ZABs constructed employing air electrodes including S/N/CNT exhibited excellent performance, characterized by a high open-circuit potential of 1.39 V and a substantial peak power density of 123 mW cm−2. 4.2.1.1 EC based on functionalized and heteroatom doped graphene polymer Graphene has recently garnered attention for its unique applications in electrolyzers, metal-air batteries, and PEMFCs. Gr has been employed as an alternative support for Pt. Functionalized Gr is considered a promising nanofiller for the next generation due to its comparable chemical and physical attributes and cost-effective fabrication compared to carbon nanotubes. Graphene is commonly used as a replacement for carbon black due to its mechanical strength, superior conductivity, and surface area. Xu et al. [260] presented a pioneering study where they introduced edge-rich and dopant-free graphene as a very effective catalyst for the ORR. The electrochemical experiments demonstrated the exceptional ORR efficiency of graphene with a high concentration of edges, following a 4e- pathway. Additionally, edge-rich CNT and Gr exhibited improved ORR performance, emphasizing the crucial role of edge carbon in enhancing the performance of ORR EC. Liu et al. [261] developed metal-free catalysts for both the OER and ORR in FCs. The study successfully produced oxygen-functionalized Gr with abundant edges by exfoliating it in situ on carbon fibers using Ar plasma treatment. Compared to pure carbon cloth (CC), the plasma-etched carbon cloth (P-CC) demonstrated a greater specific surface area, resulting in the creation of more active sites for OER and ORR. In addition, P-CC exhibited strong inherent electron conductivity. Statistical investigations have demonstrated that P-CC has a relatively small overpotential, similar to EC based on Pt. This can be due to the presence of defects and O2 doping. The research of Zhang et al. [262] introduces a direct and efficient technique for producing highly efficient EC on carbon support. The modified ORR activity of N-doped carbon (NC) catalysts can be related to the greater electronegativity of nitrogen in comparison to carbon atoms. Experimental evidence has shown that the presence of a higher density of positive charges on the carbon atoms that are connected has a beneficial effect on the ability of O2 molecules to be adsorbed, hence improving the performance of the ORR. Lai et al. [263] introduced two distinct methods for producing N-doped Gr and elucidated its application as a metal-free catalyst to investigate the catalytic active center for the ORR. N-doped Gr was fabricated via annealing GO in ammonia (NH3) or N-containing polymer/rGO nanocomposite. The study delved into the influence of nitrogen precursors and temperature on the EC's efficiency. The bonding state of the nitrogen atom significantly impacted the ORR activity. The process of annealing GO with NH3 resulted in the formation of pyridinic nitrogen and graphitic nitrogen centers. On the other hand, annealing PANI/rGO and PPy/rGO led to the production of pyrrolic and pyridinic nitrogen moieties. The pyridinic nitrogen had a significant favorable effect on the starting potential. At the same time, the EC's catalytic efficacy was determined by the graphitic nitrogen, which was responsible for evaluating the maximum current. Chemically modifying carbon with other elements is an extremely efficient method in electrocatalytic usage. This method modifies the electron-donor characteristics of carbon and, as a result, enhances catalytic efficiency. In recent times, many advanced synthetic methods have been used to reveal micropores, which play a vital role in providing space for active sites involved in the ORR in PEMFCs. The synthesis approach is crucial in the development of carbon compounds with a high nitrogen content. When utilizing a nitrogen-containing precursor such as melamine or polyacrylonitrile, carbon material with inert nitrogen compounds can be obtained, altering the electronic structure. Alternatively, the introduction of nitrogen into nanocarbon material can be achieved by chemically modifying it with N-containing reactive elements like HNO3 or NH3CH4N2O. This process leads to the formation of nitrogen complexes, specifically at the edges and boundaries of Gr structures. The impact of doping on the electrochemical efficiency is often linked to three characteristics of the dopant: (I) the electron counts in the outside layer, (II) the atomic dimensions, and (III) the electronegativity. Nitrogen, which is the element that is employed as a dopant the most frequently, has a size that is comparable to that of carbon and possesses one additional electron in its outer shell in comparison to the carbon component. Nitrogen can exist in four different bonding forms: (I) pyridinic N (N1); (II) pyrrolic N (N2); (III) graphitic N (N3-N4); (IV) oxidized pyridinic N (N5). The N1 and N2 atoms are found near the periphery or in areas of imperfections, whereas the N3-N4 atoms substitute carbon atoms within the structure's interior. Pyridinic nitrogen can also occur in its oxidized state, denoted as N5. The introduction of nitrogen has been observed to enhance the electron-donor characteristics of carbon, thereby improving ORR activity. The increased activity can be attributed to two factors: (I) the presence of a single electron pair on pyridinic N and (II) the existence of extra electrons in the p-orbitals of the carbon scaffold. The precise characteristics of active sites in N-doped carbon substances continue to be a topic of investigation. Several scholars claim that pyridinic nitrogen (N) contributes to the activity of ORR, whereas others indicate the involvement of graphitic nitrogen. Recent research suggests that both sites may be equally important for ORR efficiency [264,265]. The resulting EC exhibits high performance in both acidic and basic media, along with great stability and remarkable tolerance to methanol. Furthermore, a core graphitic shell structure's existence influences the efficiency of mass transport in the ORR process from the electrolyte to the catalytic sites. This research demonstrates the effective combination of nanostructures, resulting in a highly promising EC for ORR in PEMFCs. Zhang et al. [266] fabricated a structure resembling a flower using WN and N-C to improve the efficiency of the ORR. The increased electrocatalytic performance is attributed to the existence of dual active sites comprising of N-C and distinctive flower-like WN nanostructures, which facilitate an almost complete 4-electron route. Therefore, this economically efficient EC made from NMPs has the potential to replace Pt/C. It has been demonstrated that the introduction of heteroatoms into Gr or carbon has a major impact on the catalytic efficacy of these materials, and the ORR performance of doped Gr or carbon is highly supported by theoretical investigations. Scientists have identified heteroatom-doped Gr as a potential source for ORR in PEMFCs. They propose that the heteroatom source itself can serve as a very effective EC. Liang et al. [267] explored the co-doping effect of graphitic N and pyridinic N on the structural stability of NDG through theoretical calculations. Through the examination of the co-doping of graphitic N and pyridinic N within various porous structures, it was observed that co-doping enhanced the stability of the material. The combination of graphitic N and pyridinic N in triangular pores exhibited the highest stability compared to all other co-doped structures. Calculations of free energy change indicated that pyridinic N-doped GQDs (pN-GQDs) exhibited superior catalytic activities compared to pyrrolic N-doped GQDs (prN-GQDs). The results may illuminate the impact of various N-doping configurations and adsorbed species on electrocatalytic activities, offering theoretical guidance for the design and advancement of carbon-based ORR electrochemical cells for FCs and metal-air batteries. Li et al. [269] have recently shown that changes in the carbon nanoscale work function are the cause of the enhanced performance in ORR. In addition, the inclusion of other heteroatoms such as phosphorus (P), boron (B), and sulfur (S) in carbon materials has garnered interest due to their ability to effectively enhance the activity of ORR by introducing extra-active sites. Carbon nanohybrids containing dopants such as S, P, and B, or co-doped with N, have been successfully synthesized. These nanohybrids exhibit enhanced electrocatalytic activity for the ORR as a result of the synergistic effects caused by the presence of the doped elements. A readily available and economical method has been utilized to produce BCN-Gr on a large scale, with the ability to control the quantities of N and B doping. This is achieved by subjecting GO to thermal annealing in the presence of boric acid and ammonia gas. When heteroatoms are added to Gr or CNTs, the electrical structure changes, creating active spots where O2 can be adsorbed. In N-C materials such as Gr or carbon, active sites are present at carbon atoms that are next to the doped N atoms. This is because the N atoms have a high electronegativity, causing the nearby carbon atoms to become polarized. Additionally, due to the poor electronegativities of B or P atoms, dopants serve as active sites for carbon materials that have been doped with any or both of these elements. In the case of carbon materials that have been doped with sulfur, active sites are created at the zigzag edge point, which is either close to carbon or where doped sulfur atoms are present. Du et al. [270] discovered that by pyrolyzing zero-dimensional C-quantum dots, they were able to construct a metal-free, effective ORR EC. This EC was made of P and N co-doped three-dimensional porous carbon. The NPCN-900, as it was originally produced, demonstrates exceptional electrocatalytic activity for the ORR and displays high resistance to methanol in a wide range of pH levels in water-based solutions. The remarkable ORR performance of NPCN-900 can be primarily ascribed to its unique three-dimensional porous architectures, abundant edge defects, high specific surface area, and the effective incorporation of P and N. This study not only acknowledges the shift from zero-dimensional colloidal quantum dots (CQDs) to three-dimensional heteroatoms functionalized porous carbon nanomaterial but also showcases a straightforward and template-free fabrication approach to attain exceptional catalytic efficiency and improved durability in metal-free ORR EC for FCs. 4.2.1.2 Conductive polymer (CP) materials Polythiophene (PTh), poly (3-methyl thiophene) (PMeT), polyaniline (PANI), polypyrrole (PPy), and poly (3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) are conductive polymers (CPs) that possess a combination of metallic and polymeric characteristics. This makes them well-suited for a wide range of purposes because they are cost-effective, highly electronic conductive, and have unique redox properties. In recent times, there has been a growing interest in investigating the potential of CPs for non-precious ORR electrocatalysis, employing three distinct methodologies: (I) serving as standalone ORR EC; (II) integrating NMP complexes into the CP matrix; (III) functioning as a N-C precursor material for pyrolyzed M-N x /C EC, where M = Fe, Ni, Co, Mn, etc. The ORR results of Co3O4/poly(EDOT-F) are discussed in Table 4 [271]. Conductive polymers possess distinct intrinsic characteristics, including electrochemical, electrical/electronic, and optical properties, which are associated with their p-conjugated bonds, including both single and double bonds. CPs possess several benefits, such as low density, flexibility, chemical variety, corrosion resistance, morphology, and adjustable conductivity. Hence, CPs have a wide range of applications, including organic light-emitting diodes, thin film transistors, supercapacitors, organic solar cells, sensors, FCs, and electrochromic displays. There exist innovative techniques to enhance the characteristics of CPs. The CP nanocomposites can consist of carbon nanofibers, graphene, and CNT. Percolation theory provides a rationale for the conductive properties of CPs. This paper elucidates the transition from having insulating properties to acquiring conductive properties in the context of CPs, which is facilitated by the existence of conductive fillers. However, even with the addition of more fillers, the percolation threshold remains unchanged, presenting a continuous obstacle to the electrical conductivity of CPs. Research has been conducted over several decades to investigate the electrical conductivity and characteristics of organic polymers. Particular attention has been paid by researchers to the electrical conductivity of CPs. Nanofillers, such as CNTs, fullerene, CB, graphene, and CNFs are crucial for CPs because of their enhanced functionality in comparison to conventional polymers. These qualities include electrical and thermal conductivity, electromagnetic shielding, easy formability, lightweight, cost-effectiveness, etc. Two crucial factors impact the conductive network in CPs: dispersion and distribution. Another crucial issue in composite materials is the interface between the polymer chain and nanofillers, which has a significant impact on the mechanical and electrical characteristics. Surface modifications, whether covalent or non-covalent, are a method used to improve interfacial interactions. Covalent methods can create robust C–C bonds between the molecular chains of a polymer matrix and nanofillers, resulting in improved mechanical characteristics of the polymer. Conversely, the electrical characteristics of carbon nanofillers may be impaired as a result of the rigorous surface treatment. The non-covalent approach allows for the preservation of the integrity of electrical characteristics. When creating nanocomposite polymers, several elements need to be considered, such as the selection of nanofillers, the polymer matrix and production process, and the interfacial behavior. Furthermore, a comprehensive understanding of the electrical characteristics of CPs is essential for their optimal use. Khomenko et al. [272] investigated the ORR performance of carbon-based CPs with nitrogen or sulfur in their fundamental composition, including PMeT, PANI, PPy, PEDOT, and PTh. Martinez-Millan et al. [273] examined carbon-supported PANI, PPy, and PMeT, revealing ORR occurrences at high overpotentials with open circuit potentials of 0.48, 0.62, and 0.63 V vs. NHE, respectively. [274] designed and successfully constructed a thiophene-enriched fully conjugated 3D COF (BUCT-COF-11) by an all-thiophene-linked saddle-shaped building block (COThTh-CHO). The BUCT-COF-11 illustrated superior semiconducting properties with intrinsic metal-free ORR activity. The AEMFCs achieved a significant peak power density of up to 493 mW cm−2 using the COF as the cathode catalyst. DFT simulations demonstrated that the addition of thiophene to the COF not only enhanced its conductivity but also optimized its electronic structure, resulting in an increased performance in the ORR. This paper represents the initial use of COFs as catalysts in FCs, highlighting the significant potential of completely conjugated 3D COFs as semiconductors in the field of energy. Chen et al. [275] constructed PTh-COF/CNT as ORR EC with narrowed energy band gaps. Similarly, the performance of PTh-COF/CNT was evaluated as a cathode catalyst in metal-free AEMFCs, resulting in a peak power density of 176 mW cm−2 at a current density of 533 mA cm−2. The DFT simulation demonstrated that the electron cloud distribution of interlayer conjugated polythiophene was optimized, resulting in an enhancement of the ORR performance. This study not only offered a fresh understanding of the fabrication of a completely interconnected covalent organic framework but also advanced the progress of novel metal-free oxygen reduction reaction catalysts. Nayak et al. [276] examined the ORR characteristics of a range of electropolymerized PEDOT films. To comprehend the factors that affect the features of ORR, the researchers conducted experiments where they manipulated the counterion (using monomeric or polymeric forms), included a hydroxyl-terminated EDOT monomer into the polymer structure, or introduced a conductivity enhancer into the reaction mixture. The counterion type and the presence of the conductivity enhancer regulated the immaculate doping level of the polymer in PEDOT films, thereby influencing the ORR route. Significant levels of inherent doping resulted in films in which H2O2 was the primary ORR product. This study proposes methodologies for developing conducting polymers that exhibit enhanced performance for electrocatalytic applications. Taxi et al. [277] developed a method to create cost-effective and highly efficient EC for ORR, to advance the use of fuel cells in commercial applications. The researchers presented findings on a newly developed porous carbon structure that exhibits exceptional catalytic performance. N and P co-doped carbon structures were fabricated using the impregnation process, with sustainable cotton fibers (CF) serving as the template. The specific surface area of PANI-SF@CF materials increased to 857.9 m2 g−1 after undergoing pyrolysis. In an alkaline medium, the metal-free EC showed exceptional ORR activity (E onset = 1.1 V, J L = 6.83 mA cm−2) and long-term stability. Quantum-chemical calculations were employed to gain deeper insights into the ORR catalyzed by these polymers. All conducting polymers, except PEDOT, exhibited ORR efficiency at elevated overpotentials. It has been proposed that for these polymers to engage with O2, they must exist in their reduced forms, which are commonly attained at electrochemically low potentials. PEDOT, however, remained unreduced in the required potential range for ORR, rendering it inert to the reaction. Research indicated that electron donor heteroatoms, particularly nitrogen in PPy and PANI, contributed more significantly to activity enhancement compared to sulfur atoms in PTh and PMeT. The results are consistent with previous observations made on M-N x /C catalysts, providing a foundation for future research endeavors focused on improving the ORR efficiency of CPs and their composites. 4.2.1.3 The enhancement of ORR performance by the integration of TM macrocycles in CPs Extensive research has been conducted on the inclusion of catalytically active NMP macrocycle components inside a CP chain. Coutanceau et al. investigated the process of immobilizing Fe and Co tetra-sulfonated phthalocyanines (FeTsPc or CoTsPc) within PPy and PANI materials [278]. Their findings indicated an enhanced ORR performance for PPy-encapsulated Pc macrocycles, while minimal differences were observed in the case of PANI. Over a decade later, several studies delved into the encapsulation of CoTPP macrocycles or CoTPPS in PPy on various supports, revealing some ORR activities. Despite demonstrating catalytic activity for ORR at elevated overpotentials, these materials exhibited relatively low activities, consistent with the typical behavior of non-precious macrocycle catalysts in the absence of heat treatment. Ma et al. [279] developed CNTs@CoPc-CPs as a pyrolysis-free electrocatalyst for the ORR. They proposed an efficient linker engineering technique to modify the electronic states of metallophthalocyanine conjugated polymers and elucidate the crucial function of organic linkers in promoting the ORR. By altering the electrical properties of organic linkers from terephthalaldehyde (TA) to 2,5-thiophene carboxaldehyde (TDA) and subsequently, to thieno/thiophene-2,5-dicarboxaldehyde (bTDA), the associated CNTs@CoPc-CPs demonstrated progressively enhanced electrocatalytic performance for the ORR. Furthermore, theoretical calculations indicated that the transfer of charge from CoPc units to electron-withdrawing linkers (such as TDA and bTDA) facilitated the delocalization of Co d-orbital electrons, consequently leading to a downshift in the Co d-band energy level. Hence, the Co centers that were more positively charged had improved binding energy towards intermediates relevant to the ORR. As a result, they exhibited a well-balanced adsorption/desorption pathway, leading to a considerable boost in electrocatalytic ORR. Singh et al. [280] developed a cobalt-based phenanthroline and triphenylamine-linked mesoporous polymer using a donor-acceptor strategy for trifunctional electrocatalysis (Co@TBPA-phen). Co@TBPA-phen showed considerable electrochemical activity for the ORR with a low onset potential of 0.80 V against RHE and for the HER with an overpotential of −486 mV at 10 mA cm−2. However, just 6.3 wt% Co stabilized Co@TBPA-phen facilitates the OER at an overpotential of 480 mV at 10 mA cm−2, alongside the ORR (E onset = 0.82 V vs. RHE) and HER (−335 mV at 10 mA cm−2) at diminished overpotentials. DFT simulations revealed the descriptor for each reaction and confirmed that easily produced polymers were exceptional donor–acceptor pairings. The natural bond orbital analysis elucidated orbital interactions and charge transfer in the ORR and OER, confirming cobalt stabilization in Co@TBPA-phen in Co(0) and Co(II) oxidation states. RZABs exhibited a specific capacity of 723 mAh g−1 with a notable discharge potential of 1.2 V, and an open circuit voltage of 1.51 V, maintaining a consistent voltage window of 0.75 V for as many as 108 cycles. 5 Conclusions and perspectives Many decades have passed since the beginning of the search for alternatives to Pt EC for the reduction of O2 in FCs. To improve the ORR activity, several novel techniques and models have been devised, involving strategies such as tuning absorbency, doping configurations, and nanostructure preparation. Carbon nanomaterials have been identified as highly efficient catalysts for ORR in FCs. These materials (Gr and CNT that are doped with two different elements) can serve as highly efficient substrates for catalysts with nanostructured features. This support role serves to inhibit the movement and buildup of nanostructures, while simultaneously improving the catalytic efficiency by leveraging the combined action of the supports and structures. Additionally, porous MOFs and doped carbon nanostructures have shown great potential as catalysts. NNM-based SACs are intriguing due to their potential for more active sites, yet there is a need for a more precise fabrication approach to achieve optimal catalysts. Currently, there is an increasing desire to acquire ORR catalysts that exhibit superior efficiency in acidic environments as opposed to basic environments. Hence, forthcoming investigations should prioritize the extensive surface area of nanomaterials and the presence of additional active sites, to achieve improved electrochemical efficiency. Although there are several difficulties in this area, the growing interest in electrochemical reduction using NNM catalysts suggests a hopeful outlook for future advancements. Additional endeavors should be focused on the systematic development of exceptionally effective electrodes and the exploration of reduction processes. The use of NNM catalysts in PEMFCs has the potential to have a wide range of applications for ORR. The primary objective continues to be the advancement of EC for PEMFCs. For the industrial fabrication of catalysts, maintaining quality control for stable FC activity is crucial. The durability of Pt catalysts directly impacts the longevity and economic efficiency of PEMFCs. Maintaining high activity throughout the electrochemical operation is referred to as enhancing their stability to some extent. Given the limited durability of Pt/C, improving the stability can be achieved by optimizing the size and crystal structure of Pt. Smaller particles have a higher surface energy, which causes them to be more prone to aggregation and thermodynamic instability. Likewise, the breakdown of the Pt/C system occurs due to carbon corrosion at high potential. The oxygenated species have a higher affinity for binding to the Pt particles, causing them to separate from the support. This detachment occurs by either particle movement or spillage on the surface, resulting in the subsequent redeposition and aggregation of the particles. Additionally, the presence of radicals, sulphonic groups, and other substances on the surface of Pt can cause significant deterioration. Therefore, increasing the size and optimizing the crystal structure of the catalyst might help reduce the merging and solidification of Pt. Nevertheless, the increased size may result in a drop in the effective ECSA and activity, as a consequence of the lower ratio of surface area to volume. However, it is possible to accept a slight loss in activity in exchange for the enhanced long-term stability of the catalyst. The next concept involves the creation of intricate multidimensional Pt nanostructures that exhibit resistance to migration, dissolution, and aggregation, in contrast to the isotropic nanoparticle. Using a metal with a greater oxidation potential to stabilize Pt, which is resistant to corrosion and sintering, is a promising strategy. Another potential technique is to provide a protective coating that prevents direct contact between a less resistant non-noble metal and a corrosive environment. However, achieving an optimized uniform coating, particularly carbon coating at high temperatures, remains difficult because of its potential to impede the effective interaction of reactants with the active sites. Although Pt has undergone size and structural improvements, it still faces significant challenges in terms of poor stability and increased cost. Hence, alloying is a more favorable option for enhancing durability against particle dissolving and reducing costs. While alloying procedures may be effective in meeting durability criteria, Pt alloys still have issues such as metal corrosion, leaching, and overflow of surface particles. These problems can result in redeposition and aggregation, resulting in a significant decline in activity. Similarly, alloying provides the opportunity to precisely adjust the composition, strain, or ligand effect at the surface, and enhance it with additional anti-corrosion components to safeguard against particle spillover under long-term circumstances. To make PGM-free materials economically viable, it is crucial to make considerable improvements in the performance of the Pt/C electrocatalyst, addressing issues such as Pt ripening, carbon corrosion, and agglomeration. Although there have been significant increases in ORR activity, the lack of molecular-level understanding or control of the iron active sites is now impeding future progress. The intricate and labor-intensive manufacturing techniques are expected to hinder the progress of MOF-based SACs with outstanding efficiency. Hence, to satisfy the need for electrochemical analysis results and, eventually, operational uses in energy technologies, it is necessary to search for convenient and inexpensive synthesis processes for the manufacturing of large-scale catalysts. However, there are still technological obstacles that must be overcome to create nanostructures that may be used in practical uses. The precise details of the reaction process and the specific active sites involved in the ORR are still not fully understood, especially when considering detailed simulations and theoretical calculations. The development of effective ORR EC continues to depend largely on experimental measurements and data. Hence, it is crucial to promote comprehensive and methodical theoretical investigation into the nanomaterial design and fabrication strategies of ORR EC for PEMFCs. The following conclusions and future perspectives were drawn from this review (I) Two different methodologies were utilized to study EC for the ORR in acidic conditions, including both theoretical and experimental approaches. The initial methodology involved employing computational design as a means of forecasting and examining a significant quantity of NPs. Afterward, the most favorable candidates for the ORR were created. The second method involved conducting experimental studies on NPs, followed by the use of computational chemistry to examine the molecular-level components that contribute to the enhancement of ORR electrocatalytic performance. (II) The slab and cluster techniques were applied at the theoretical level to simulate EC in the course of both theoretical and experimental research of metal EC based on platinum. Particularly noteworthy is the fact that the slab approach was utilized over the cluster approach more frequently. (III) Theoretical and empirical examinations of Pt EC have shown that the electrocatalytic performance and intermediates generated during the ORR process are greatly affected by various surface configurations of Pt. The study yielded significant findings that enhanced our comprehension of the function of support materials in the activity and durability of Pt EC for the ORR in acidic environments. (IV) A multitude of integrated theoretical and practical investigations have been carried out on EC composed of platinum and another metal for the ORR. An analysis was conducted on the impact of the second metal (strain, ligand, and ensemble effects) on the Pt surface employing a range of experimental methods and DFT simulations. Nevertheless, there is a dearth of theoretical and practical research investigating the performance and durability of Pt-based bimetallic catalysts when supported by innovative materials including CNTs, Gr, and hybrid supports. Hence, it is imperative for future studies to prioritize the investigation of this aspect, given the well-documented significance of support materials in influencing the performance and durability of EC. (V) Currently, there is a limited amount of research that examines the impact of size on catalytic activity and stability. This is mostly due to the difficulty in modeling NPs or clusters that are larger than 2 nm. (VI) Generally, DFT computations that make use of generalized gradient approximation functionals are utilized extensively in both experimental and theoretical research. Incorporating more complex approximations, such as hybrid functionals, is necessary to provide a description that is more accurate of the interaction that occurs between ORR species and metallic surfaces. Therefore, future research endeavors should prioritize the following aspects I. Additional progress in electrocatalytic efficiency is urgently required, specifically in acidic solutions. This imperative is essential to delve deeper into the fundamental catalytic mechanisms. II. NMP catalysts with electrochemically active surface area (ESA) nanostructures should be explored as a means to augment the ORR performance, to increase the number of active sites. III. The catalytic capabilities of metal-free EC rely on the introduction of heteroatoms into carbonaceous materials, which act as defects to improve catalytic efficiency. The development of a metal-free EC with a hierarchical porous structure can offer several advantages by offering various active sites. However, there is a requirement for easy fabrication approaches for this structure due to the lack of control over the existing pyrolysis process employed in its synthesis. Additional investigation is necessary to comprehend the characteristics of the active sites in the developing electrocatalyst to support its eventual widespread commercialization and use in catalyzing reactions in PEMFC. IV. The area of CPs has the potential for future growth in several aspects, including the creation of novel molecules, the exploration of new commercial applications, and the progress of basic research that enhances our understanding of materials. Electron-conducting polymers can be intentionally created to have the ability to expand, as indicated by the first statement. Furthermore, it is crucial to comprehend that most CPs function as hole transporters, indicating that the electron mobility in organic solids is equivalent to that of holes. Despite notable advancements, N-doped CPs have not yet attained the stability and conductivity levels of the P-doped polymers. It is crucial to develop synthetic methods for both new and old CPs. V. Theoretical calculations, coupled with experimental approaches, should be employed to uncover fundamental ORR mechanisms and identify active sites. This integrated approach facilitates the design of novel catalyst nanostructures. VI. MOF-based catalysts have been seldom taken into account for chemical synthesis, including CO2 reduction. MOF-based catalysts offer a straightforward means of achieving enhanced catalytic stability. There is a need to modify the catalytic activity and stability of MOF-based nanomaterials, especially in acidic electrolytes. There is a strong need for efficient and reliable nano-EC based on MOFs that possess certain properties for use in energy conversion applications. The primary driving force in the foreseeable future is the exploration of novel nanomaterials. The new nanomaterials must surpass the existing obstacles and must fulfill the following requirements. (a) The synthetic raw material and synthesis process is inexpensive. (b) The catalyst exhibits exceptional catalytic activity for the ORR and may be used in commercial applications. (c) The catalyst demonstrates stability that effectively maintains the performance of the commercial device over several years. (d) The catalyst has the potential to be scaled up for mass commercialization. Hence, future study needs further endeavors. VII. EC composed of single atoms requires extensive research and investigation. There is a strong need for detailed investigations and a methodical evaluation of the mechanisms involved in the ORR in basic and acidic electrolytic conditions. The preparation methods for various types of SACs are time-consuming. Thus, there is a significant need for universally applicable protocols that can be refined and enhanced to easily synthesize a wide range of SACs. This is a challenging task when it comes to producing SACs on a large scale for industrial purposes. The advancement of SACs utilizing non-precious metals is a highly intriguing and significant breakthrough due to its unique characteristics and affordability. Consequently, a more extensive experimental investigation is necessary to explore the potential of non-precious SACs as a promising avenue for future electrocatalysis advancements. It is required to use modern methodologies and theoretical calculations to comprehend the non-precious SAC and the electrocatalytic process of a single active site. Calculating the structure's SAC is crucial through theoretical measurements using a novel manufacturing process and an innovative catalytic system. Efforts are necessary to investigate the active SACs that exhibit commendable activity, prolonged durability, and affordable cost. Investigating SAC with improved characteristics is crucial for EC and its relevance to energy technology. VIII. Advancing the development of in-situ/high-resolution characterization methods, like XANES, EXAFS, HAADFSTEM, and XPS, to accurately determine electronic structure, surface species, atomic-level distribution, coordination information, and other relevant factors. Various methodologies can yield more precise elucidations of active site creation, facilitating a comprehensive comprehension of enhanced performance concerning activity, stability, and resistance. Mahdi Soleimani Moghaddam got his PhD from the University of Mazandaran, Babolsar, Iran. His research interests include clean energy, electrochemical sciences, quantum technology, and especially PEM fuel cells. Meysam Seyfi Kafshgari got his PhD from Babol Noshirvani University of Technology. His research interests include wastewater treatment, gas sensors, electrochemical sciences, nano-biomaterials, and MOF technology. Ali Bahari is a Professor in the Faculty of Science at the University of Mazandaran, Babolsar, Iran. He is an expert in electrochemistry and clean energy. He is the author or coauthor of more than 50 papers in these fields. Leila Asadi Kafshgari got her PhD from Babol Noshirvani University of Technology. She received her master’s degree in Chemical Engineering-Polymer Engineering for her work on the fabrication and application of magnetic nano-adsorbent at Shomal University in 2016. Her current research interest covers polymer engineering, DFT modeling, and electrochemical sciences. Adeleh Jafari is a researcher in the Department of Solid-State Physics of the University of Mazandaran, Babolsar, Iran. Her research interests include electrochemistry, clean energy, and PEM fuel cells

coredata.dc:description: The main challenge preventing the broad commercial use of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) is the dependence on noble metals, specifically electrocatalyst (EC) based on platinum (Pt) at the cathode, which is indispensable for assisting the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in fuel cells (FCs). Research on EC-containing non-noble metal (NNM) has been considerable over the past few decades to minimize costs and reduce the excessive loading of EC based on Pt. This review is aimed at improving the reliability and stability of non-precious metal EC. To achieve a feasible ORR, Pt-based EC is crucial for the widespread commercial applications of PEMFCs. The review emphasizes improving ORR performance, stability, and cost-effectiveness in catalysts that are not precious metals. The article examines the advancements in non-precious nanomaterial-based EC, highlighting different types that have improved ORR efficiency. The review suggests future possibilities and directions for further improvement in designing and constructing EC with high efficiency and low costs for PEMFCs.
